stealing, on the 21st of June , 2lbs. weight of bacon, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Francis Proctor
.

STEPHEN HALLETT
. I was in Lisson-grove
on the 21st of June - I saw the prisoner take a piece of bacon from a board outside the prosecutor's shop; she put it under her child's clothes; I told the prosecutor's son, who took her with it.

CHARLES CLARK
(Police-constable D 117). I took the prisoner, and have the bacon.

JAMES PROCTOR
. I believe this to be my brother
Francis Proctor
's property - the prisoner had got one hundred yards from the shop when she was stopped with it.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw it on the ground - I took it up, and offered it to a little girl; she said it was not hers.

GUILTY . Aged 59. -
Confined One Month .

1616.
JOSEPH ADOLPHUS CLIFFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of June , 2 live tame fowls, price 4s., and 8 live tame chickens, price 5s. , the property of
John Fry
.

JOHN FRY
. I live at Hammersmith
. I lost two hens and eight chickens on the 15th of June, from my yard at the back of my house; they were safe the evening before - I missed them about half-past five o'clock that morning; my hen-house was not locked, but was surrounded by a wall and a fence; on the Monday following the prisoner came and asked me if I did not want some person to work for me - I said No, and asked what he had done with the fowls that he and another had taken from me; he said he had not seen them - I asked if the Policeman had not stopped him, and if he had not told him his name was Field; he said No - I asked him if he had any objection to go to the station; he said No, and I sent for a Policeman, who took him to Shepherd's-bush station, where he had been stopped, and they knew him - one of my hens was a little game hen, and was lame, having had one of her legs broken - two of the chickens had small top-knots on their necks; the prisoner lived at Paddington.

HENRY BEVAN
(Police-constable T 108). I met the prisoner at half-past three o'clock in the morning, at Shepherd's-bush; he had a small pheasant hen in an apron, and eight speckled chickens in a bag - another lad had a small game hen; the prisoner owned that he had taken the fowls, and sold them at Paddington for 6s. 9d.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor sent to my mother, and said he had a job to do; I went to him, and he sent me to Shepherd's-bush - they said I was the boy, but I am innocent.

JURY to
HENRY BEVAN
. Q. Are you positive this is the boy you saw? A. Yes, I swear positively he is.
COURT. Q. Was he taken before the Magistrate? A. Yes; he there made this statement, which is signed by Mr. Rawlings - (read).
The prisoner says the other boy asked me to go with him to his master's to fetch the fowls; he said they belonged to him; he got over the wall, and got them.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1617.
JOHN JACKSON
was indicted for
feloniously forging, on the 16th of June , a request for delivery of goods .
SECOND COUNT, for feloniously uttering the same.

JOHN CONNERY
. I am in the service of
Joseph Samuel Lischer
and
William Joseph Lischer
; they live in Thomas-street
, Whitechapel, and are starch maker
s. On the 16th of June, the prisoner, whom I had not seen before, came to the counting-house, and brought me this order; Mr. Jones has been a customer of our's for some years, but I did not know Mr. Ward - I suspected it was not right, and I asked the prisoner if he would take a bill then, or whether I should send it with the rest of the goods on Monday - he said I might do as I liked, but he thought I had better send it on Monday; I then said very well, and called a man to weigh the starch, but motioned for him to shut the door; I then turned to the prisoner, and said, "Where did you get this order?" he said from Mr. Jones - I asked him if he knew Mr. Noyes, and some other persons, in whose name I knew he had got some things - he said "You seem to know all about it:" I said "I know more than you wish; I will send for Mr. Jones" - he said "You need not;" I said "Yes, I will, for my own satisfaction;" he then said "I did not get it from Mr. Jones, but from a person I do not know." - (Order read.)
16th June, 1832.

Gentlemen - Please to let the bearer have seven papers of starch, and send 3 cwt. in on Monday or Tuesday, for
Edward Jones
. W. WARD.
3, Raven-row.

EDWARD JONES
. I am a grocer, and a customer of the prosecutor's. I have no person in my employ of the name of Ward - this is not my writing, nor was such an order given by me.
Prisoner. Q. Do you authorize any persons to write orders for you? A. We very seldom send orders in writing, but send the clerk.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been made the dupe of a party I cannot find, and must throw myself on the mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1618.
GEORGE WILKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March , 1 watch, value 10l.; 1 watch-chain, value 2l., and 1 watch-key, value 1l. , the goods of
Clark Stanley
.

BENJAMIN HUET
. I am a hackney-coachman ; the prisoner is the same. On the 20th of June I was acting as waterman at the stand at Old-street
; the prisoner came and laid himself all along on the pavement - he was drunk, or pretended to be so; I shook him up, and said, "George, don't lay here, you impede the footway" - he got up, called the Policeman, and said I had stolen his watch; I was taken, but nothing was found on me, but 1s. 1d. - the watch was found in his own waistcoat pocket, and then he said I had taken it from one pocket, and put into another - I was taken, but the next day he did not appear against me; I was discharged, and the officer told me to give him in charge if I saw him, which I did, and this watch was found on him, which he accused me of stealing.

JOHN FLETCHER
. I was sent for, and took the witness in charge; this watch was found on the prisoner when he was taken.

SAMSON HENRY PERRY
. I am an inspector of Police. When the watch was found, I suspected it was one which I had seen advertised, and I apprised the prosecutor of it.

CLARK STANLEY
. I am out of business . I took a coach, on the 27th of March, from the stand in Old-street; Holmes drove it - we went to Mile-end turnpike; Mrs. Wilkins was with me - in about an hour after I left the coach, I was going to bed, and missed my watch; I know I had it when I entered the coach, as I had taken it out to see the time, and I think I left it in the coach; this is it - I have had it thirty years; it had a gold case, a gold chain, and a gold key, but they are all missing.

ANN WILKINS
. I was with Mr. Stanley; he had his watch when he entered the coach - in consequence of what he said, I went to the stand the next day, and saw the driver of the coach.

THOMAS HOLMES
. I drove the coach with this lady and gentleman, and sat them down between eleven and twelve o'clock at night; I then went back to the Pavilion, and staid till it was over - I then went home, and put up the coach in the dark, at Mr. Thomas', my employer; the prisoner is horse-keeper there - it was his duty to look after the horses, and wash the coach; I never saw the watch till the inspector showed it to me - I heard of the circumstance, and named it to the prisoner; he said he knew nothing of it - I also told my master of it.
Prisoner. Q. Could you take out the seats without seeing it? A. Yes, I took them out in the dark.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it just as it is now, in Petticoat-lane, and have had it in my pocket ever since.

GUILTY . Aged 50. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1619.
ELIZABETH RICHARDSON
was indicted for for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
George Henry Hinkins
.

MARY LOWN
. I live opposite Mr. Hinkins. I was sitting at my father's window on the 6th of June, and saw the prisoner stand on the step of the prosecutor's door, and take a pair of my shoes; my father called to a person, who went and took her with the shoes - I know she is the person.

WILLIAM DAVIS
. I was in the prosecutor's shop when the alarm was given; I went after the prisoner, and took hold of her arm - I lifted up her shawl, took the shoes from her, and brought her back; she pretended to be intoxicated.
GEORGE HENRY HINKINS. These are my shoes; I know nothing of the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 52. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1620.
BOSWILL PARKIN
was
indicted for bigamy .

JOHN ROWLAND
. I act as clerk at St. James' Westminster. I produce a certificate of a marriage at that church, which I have examined with the register; it is correct - it appears by this that on the 28th of April, 1819, Boswill Parkin and
Alice Hatfield
were married by banns.

MARY DAVEY
. I am the sister of the prisoner's first wife ; she was married unknown to my mother or me - she lived with the prisoner as his wife for nine years, and they had a little boy, who is now eleven years old; the prisoner lodged with my mother for twelve months before they were married - they still lived at my mother's, though we did not know they were married, till three or four months before the child was born, which was two years after they were married; my sister assisted my mother, who took in washing, the prisoner was a bricklayer.

Cross-examined by MR. WALESBY. Q. Are you married? A. Yes, I was not then - my sister was in the habit of sleeping with my mother, but when we found they were married, the prisoner went and bought a bedstead and bedding; they slept together after that; I do not recollect Mary Parsons; she passed, I am told, for the prisoner's mother-in-law - she is now dead; the Christian name of the prisoner, in this certificate of the baptism of their child, is Basil - I believe he gave that name to the Magistrate; I believe my sister was in the habit of going to a gentleman, named Beaumont, to get his things to wash.
COURT. Q. Did you hear the prisoner call your sister his wife? A. Yes, and he said they were married at St. James' church - my sister is here now.

JANE SIMMONS
. I have known the prisoner between three and four months; he has been known to my family for thirteen years - I lived with my sister, who keeps a grocer's shop, at Bayswater; the prisoner paid his addresses to me as a widower; I married him at St. James' church
on the 28th of May last - we lived together as husband and wife for three weeks; on the 18th of June I discovered that he was married, and his wife came to the house were we lived at, in Queen-street, Soho - he is a master bricklayer; he had no fortune with me.

Cross-examined. Q. Did your friends, who had known him so many years, raise any objection to your marriage? A. No, his little boy was living with me; he stated he was a widower, and had that child - but since this charge, he told me it was the child of a woman who was not his wife.

Prisoner's Defence. The woman who claims me as her husband, I never went to church with; she alwaysslept with her mother; I went to the chapel door when the child was christened - that is all; my name is William - I never went by any other; there is a law-suit in which I am engaged, that they want to get me out of.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined One Year .

1621.
ROBERT SIMMONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 1 water-butt, value 4s.; 1 grate, value 8s.; 2 fire-stoves, value 5s.; 10 windowsashes, value 5l.; 8 benches, value 4l.; 1 boiler, value 10s.; 4 cupboards, value 1l.; 1 sink, value 5s., and 1 leaden pipe, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Skeeles Wright
.
MR. CLARKSON declined the prosecution,
NOT GUILTY .

1622.
MARY MOON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of June , 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 1s., and 1 smock-frock, value 1s. , the goods of
William Littleboy
.

ELIZABETH LITTLEBOY
. I am the wife of
William Littleboy
. On the 7th of June I sent my daughter to the mangler's, for a bundle of things, and to Mr. Kennedy's.

CATHERINE ANN LITTLEBOY
. I am daughter of this witness. I got the bundle, and was to take it to Mr. Kennedy's, a pawnbroker, opposite Shadwell church
-I went there with it, in a basket; I put it down by my side - I saw the prisoner in the shop; I turned my head round, and missed my basket and the bundle that was in it, which were the articles stated; I went after the prisoner, and found her opposite Shadwell-market - the officer was looking after her; I am sure she is the woman.

HENRY LEE
(Police-constable K 262). I was on duty, and saw this girl crying; she said she had lost her basket of things - I found the prisoner half an hour afterwards, with this smock-frock in her possession - the other things have not been found.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the smock-frock for 1s. 6d. - I did not touch the basket.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Three Months .

1623.
MARY McLOCHLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 jacket, value 7s. , the goods of
James Furzeman
.

JAMES FURZEMAN. I am overseer of St. Giles' . On the 28th of June I sent the prisoner, who was an Irish pauper , to Mrs. Neale's, in Buckeridge-street; I went there afterwards, and found this jacket, which is mine.

MARGARET HOLLINS
. I am servant to Mrs. Neale. The prisoner came there, and brought this jacket by way of selling it to some of the lodgers, but they were not able to buy - she told me to go and make what I could of it; I pawned it for 2s., and in going back, I told Mr. Furzeman of it.
NOT GUILTY .

1624.
MARY JONES
and
SARAH ROBERTS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of June , 8 yards of muslin, value 6s., the goods of
John Harvey Knight
and another .

CHARLES DEERING
. I am in the employ of
John Harvey Knight
and his brother. On the 15th of June the prisoners came to their shop for some blue prints - I showed them some; Roberts said they were not wide enough; they did not wish to go to more than 6d. a yard -I said I had some wider at 8 1/2d; Jones then said, "You had better go and get 2 1/2d. more" - they went out, and I missed the property stated; the officer afterwards brought it.

JOHN COX
. I am a parish-officer. On the 15th of June the prisoners came running into my house, which is about half a mile from the prosecutor's - my door was open, and it rained very hard; I went out to see who was there, and found them there, pursued by Graves and a Police-constable - I heard them say, "You have stolen something;" they both strongly denied it, and the persons who pursued them felt down, but could find nothing - Roberts walked away, but Jones stopped; Ingley looked behind the street door, and took up this property.

JOHN GRAVES
. I was standing up out of the rain - the two prisoners passed by me; Jones dropped something - she stooped down, took it up again, and they ran down Bunhill-row, to the timber yard; I went up to them, and they went on to another timber yard - I made it known at the Police-station - the officer and I followed them to the passage of the house.

WILLIAM INGLEY
. I found this piece of print behind Mr. Cox's door.

ROBERT REED
(Police-constable G 19). I followed the prisoners down Bunhill-row - I came up to them in Mr. Cox's house; I searched them, but found nothing -I then went away, and was called back by Mr. Cox, who said the property was found; I took Roberts two hours afterwards - she said she knew nothing of the other girl.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Jones' Defence. I know nothing of it - I have been afflicted with fits ever since I have been here.
The prisoners received an excellent character.
JONES - GUILTY. Aged 15.
ROBERTS - GUILTY. Aged 12.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.

Judgment Respited
.

1625.
THOMAS JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; 1 seal, value 1s., and 1 watch-key, value 6d., the goods of
Frederick Estophy
, from his person .

FREDERICK ESTOPHY. I was in service at the time this happened. On the 13th of June I went to the Unicorn, in Covent-garden
, about seven o'clock in the morning - the prisoner went there about the same time; I knew nothing of him before - I went to the bar between eight and nine o'clock, and called for a glass of spirits; a dog came up, and I thought he would fly at me - I turned to put the dog away, and at that time I lost my watch; the prisoner had been close to me, and he went off directly.

THOMAS GLOVER
. I am a shoemaker, and was living with Mr. Morrison, at the Feathers; the prisoner came in there about nine o'clock, with some females - I served him with 6d. worth of gin; he pulled out a watch to see the time, and before he went away he asked me to take care of it for him, as he was going with one of those girls; I took it, and soon after Stace came and asked if I knew Johnson - I showed him the watch; in a few minutes afterwards the prisoner returned, and asked for the watch; I said Iheard it had been stolen - he said he had bought it of a young man, and he would go and take it; he went away, and did not return - I had known him when he was a waiter.

JAMES STACE
(Police-serjeant F12). I took the prisoner, and have the watch.
FREDERICK ESTOPHY. This is my watch - I am certain it was safe in my pocket when I took hold of the dog.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you come into the house at three o'clock in the morning with some other men, and sit drinking till six in the morning? A. No, it was seven o'clock before I went there - I was sober.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at the house at three o'clock in the morning: the prosecutor and two other men came there - they drank brandy-and-water; the prosecutor asked me to have some and sing them a song, which I did- we then went to the Unicorn, and got very tipsy; the prosecutor then pulled out his watch - he wanted 9s., and said he would let me have 10s. for it in the evening; I took the watch to the Feathers, and left it there.

FREDERICK ESTOPHY
. I was in the house at three o'clock in the morning.
NOT GUILTY .

1626.
THOMAS HAYNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of May , 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
Samuel Gravenor
.

JAMES WEARING
. I was in Brick-lane
on the 31st of May, and saw the prisoner take a hat from Mr. Gravenor's shop, opposite Hanbury's brewhouse; I did not pursue him, but he was taken afterwards - I lost sight of him; I know he is the person.

JOHN KNIGHT
. I saw the prisoner run away with the hat; I cried Stop thief! I know he is the boy.

ROBERT WARE
(Police-constable K 170). I was at my own door at ten minutes past eight o'clock; I heard a cry of Stop thief! and saw the prisoner run by and another boy after him, with the hat; I pursued, and took the prisoner - the other boy told him he had stolen the hat.

JOHN HUMPHRIES
. This is Mr. Samuel Gravenor's hat - I had it to sell for him.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1627.
WILLIAM GARSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 pocket-book, value 2d.; 2 skeins of thread, value 1d.; 2 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the property of
Michael Stanley
, from his person .

MICHAEL STANLEY. I am a navigator - I have known the prisoner two months; he worked for the same master. On the 17th of June he and I went to a public-house about one o'clock; I had a pocket-book in my waistcoat pocket, containing two skeins of thread, two half-crowns, two shillings, and two sixpences - I fell asleep for near three quarters of an hour; when I awoke I missed the book and its contents - I inquired of the landlord about it: I saw the prisoner again at a quarter before three o'clock, up the street; I taxed him with taking my book - he denied it; I met an officer, who took him; I saw him searched, and one of the papers, which had been in my book, two skeins of thread, and a bit of blue ribbon were found on him, and the money stated.

WILLIAM BARROW
(Police-constable G 158). I took the prisoner, and found on him the money and these articles.(Property produced and sworn to.)

BENJAMIN WALKER
. The prosecutor and the prisoner came to my house, and had a pot of porter - the prosecutor pulled out a pocket-book, and gave me a shilling; in about three-quarters of an hour he said he had been robbed of his pocket-book; I said, "If you have been robbed, it is by your mate:" he went out to look for him, and brought him back.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor asked me to go and have some beer; I had 10s. in my pocket, and was going to buy some clothes.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1628.
FREDERICK FYNN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of February , 3 coats, value 6l.; 1 pair of trousers, value 1l.; 9 yards of kerseymere, value 1l., and 2 yards of woollen cloth, value 2l., the goods of
Felix Neil
, his master .

FELIX NEIL
. I am a tailor . The prisoner was in my employ for two years and a quarter; I had stock taken, and missed some property - I employed an officer, who took the prisoner.

ALEXANDER TATE
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce all the property, which was pawned by the prisoner's wife, I believe.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer. I looked for the prisoner, and found him on the 5th of June; he said his master's property was safe - I went to the Two Spies, in Catherine-street, where I received nine duplicates, which relate to the property.
GUILTY. Aged 27.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Six Months .

1629.
WILLIAM EDMONDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 snuff-box, value 3s.; 18cigars, value 12s.; 1 canister, value 8d., and 6 ozs. of snuff, value 3s. , the goods of
John Schofield
.

JOHN SCHOFIELD. I am a tobacconist , and live in St. John's-lane
. The prisoner was in the habit of coming to my house for cigars and other things - on the 25th of June he came early in the morning; I stood on the stairs, and watched him - I saw him take a snuff-box, then a lot of cigars, and then a Scotch snuff-box from my window, and put them into his coat pocket; I sent for an officer, who took him.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was he tipsy? A. I do not consider that he was; I think he had been drinking - it was about seven o'clock in the morning.

WILLIAM ALLEN
(Police-constable G 38.) I took the prisoner - I found the property on him; he stated in going along that he had been carrying on the game for a fortnight; these things were in his coat pockets.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he not tipsy? A. I did not perceive it.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 48.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

1630.
THOMAS DOBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 book, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
George Mason
. - To which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 21. -
Judgment Respited
.

1631.
HANNAH DENNY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 6 sovereigns, the monies of
Robert John Palk
, her master .

MR. ADOLPHUS, on behalf of the prosecution, declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1632.
JAMES DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 13 handkerchiefs, value 3l., the goods of
Samuel Morgan
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

SAMUEL MORGAN LEWIS
. I am shopman to Mr. Samuel Morgan, a glover and hosier , in the Strand
. On the 26th of June the prisoner came to purchase a pair of brown cotten stockings; I showed him two parcels - he selected a pair at 1s. 6d. - he gave me 2s., and while I was getting a sixpence from the till, he snatched a parcel of handkerchiefs from the counter, and concealed them under a parcel in his arms; I came round the counter - he saw that I noticed him, and he ran out; I pursued: the officer saw and pursued him - he threw the handkerchiefs down and the stockings which he had bought.

MORRIS FREELAND
(Police-constable F 85.) I pursued, and took the prisoner; I saw him throw away these articles, and I took them up.

JOHN RATTERY
(Police-constable F 54). I have a certificate of the former conviction of the prisoner, which I got from Mr. Clark's office; I was a witness, and know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1633.
CHARLES CLEMMENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of June , 2 coats, value 3l. , the goods of
Charles Christian
.

MANWARING CHITTY
. I am in the service of Mr. Charles Christian, a land-surveyor , who lives in Lisson-grove
; I was in his office on the 18th of June, about half-past twelve o'clock, when these coats were taken from his passage - the door was open, and I saw the prisoner go out with them; I followed, and brought him back - I had never seen him before; he had got over the garden gate, which was locked.

JOHN TAYLOR
(Police-constable S 17). I took the prisoner, and have the coats.

Prisoner's Defence. A well dressed man asked me to earn 1s. - he went and got the coats, and put them on my arm; soon after this gentleman came and took me - as soon as I recovered myself I saw the man who gave them to me, running off.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1634.
ANTHONY CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June , 1 watch, value 6l.; 1 gold chain, value 3l.; 1 steel chain, value 2s.; 2 seals, value 10s.; 1 watch-key, value 1d., and 5 rings, value 5l. , the goods of
Catherine Twamley
.

CATHERINE TWAMLEY
. I lost a great number of articles at the fire in Oxford-street
; I have seen the articles stated - they are mine.

JAMES WALSH
(Police-constable C 4.) I have a watch-movement, which I got from Mr. Burgess - this medal I found on the prisoner at the station; this gold chain I received from Mr. Smart - this gold watch, four rings, six sovereigns, and a brooch, I found at Mr. Sharp's, a publican, in Green-court.

SIMON GEISMAR
. I am a jeweller. This watch-movement is mine - I lodged at the house which was burnt down.

HENRY BURGESS
. I am a builder. The prisoner gave me this watch-movement on the Thursday night after the fire; I had spoken to him, in consequence of having heard that some things had been taken, and he brought this watch-movement, and stated it was all he had got, except a ring, which appeared more like a brass ring than any thing else - I had employed him to remove the rubbish of the fire, and what was found he was to give to me, as I was in possession for the Westminster Fire-office.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Did you give him instructions to give all he found to you? A. Yes: I desired all who were there to put all they found in a fireplace-I do not know that I desired the prisoner in particular.

WILLIAM LYNCH
. I am a workman in the Five-fields, Chelsea - the prisoner lodged in my house. I saw the prisoner with this gold chain, a silver chain, and this watch, which he took out of his pocket in Mr. Smart's shop: I work for Mr. Burgess, but I was not at this job - the prisoner told me he had picked up these things in Soho-square, where Mr. Burgess' cart shot the rubbish; Mr. Smart objected to buy the watch, and he took that and some other things to Mr. Sharp's, and delivered them at the bar.

Cross-examined. Q. What was it you saw in possession of the prisoner? A. This chain and the case of this movement, which Mr. Smart bought; I believe this to be the watch which Mr. Smart would not buy - he said he picked them up in Soho-square, among the rubbish; I am a labourer - I have been in Newgate, but was not tried.

KNELLER SMART
. I am assistant to Mr.
Benjamin Smart
. He is a refiner, and lives in Princes-street. I remember the prisoner and Lynch coming there on the 4th of June, about six o'clock in the evening; the prisoner laid down this chain, this watch, and several small silver articles; he said he picked them up in Soho-square; the chain came to 2l. 2s. 7d. and the silver to 12s. 4d. - I paid him, and Lynch gave me back 1d. - they left the shop, and soon after came back, pulled out a paper, and laid down this watch - I said that did not come from the shoots; he said No, from the ruins; I said he must take that back, and give it to the firemen in possession - he said there was no one - I told him then to take it to Mr. Burgess, and he could tell him where to return it to - he hesitated, but I said I should insist upon his going to take it back - he then left the shop.
Cross-examined. Q. Had he given you his name and address? A. Yes, the first time.

ANN HIGGINS
. I live with Mr. Sharp. The prisoner called and asked me for the money that he left with Mr. Sharp; I fetched the parcel from my master, and gave it him in the passage; he was forward in drink - I followed him; he went into another public-house, and I told him he had better leave it with the girl there - I gave it her, and she gave it me again afterwards - I do not know what was in it.

MARY HIGGINS
. I am sister of this witness - she gave me the parcel, and I gave it her again.

LUCY SHARP
. I am wife of
Thomas Sharp
. On the 4th of June the prisoner delivered me a parcel, with a watch,five or six rings, six sovereigns, and a brooch in it, to take care of for him - I gave them to the officer.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it open? A. Yes, he gave it me open; I have kept money many times for him - he was tipsy.

CATHERINE TWAMLEY
. I cannot swear to the money, but I had eight sovereigns in the house.

Prisoner's Defence. If any things was found in the ruins I mentioned it; sovereigns and other things were found, and a 50l. note was picked up. Mr. Burgess gave us no order to take care of them - the place was all cleared, and I went to the square where the rubbish was, turned some of it over with my shovel, and found these things there.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1635.
MATTHEW BRYAN
and
ROBERT ISAACS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 5 lbs. of cheese, value 2s. 6d.; - lb. of snuff, value 2s. 6d., and I jar, value 1s. , the goods of
Elizabeth White
.

ELIZABETH WHITE
. I am a widow , and keep a shop in Joseph-street, St. Pancras
. On the 10th of June I lost these things.

THOMAS GOODYER
. I am an officer. On the 10th of June, about ten o'clock in the evening, I was going up the back of Cromer-street, and saw the prisoners; Isaacs had this cheese under his arm - I said "What have you there?" Bryan ran off - Isaacs threw the cheese over some rails, but I made him fetch it back again - he then said "It is Mrs. White's - Bryan got it out, and then went and got the snuff" - I then went and took Bryan.

BRYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

ISAACS -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

1636.
WILLIAM BUSHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 1 jacket, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Day
.

THOMAS DAY. I lost my jacket from on board the brig Argo, in the West India-docks
, on the 16th of June - I had seen it safe that day, on the round-house.

HENRY KING
. I am a labourer in the dock. On the 16th of June I was working on board the Argo; at twelve o'clock I went to dinner: I returned in twenty minutes, and saw the jacket on the round-house - I saw the prisoner lurking about the ship; I went a short distance, and then saw him with a jacket under his arm: I went on board, and saw the prosecutor, who said he had lost his jacket - I went and took the prisoner with it.

ROBERT TAYLOR
. I am a constable, at the West India-docks. I took the prisoner; he was a stranger.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I met a shipmate, who told me of a free-trader in the docks - I went to inquire about it, but she had got her hands; I then walked through the dock, and being warm I pulled off my jacket - I saw a lad on board this ship, and asked him for some water; I laid down my jacket, and got the water, and while doing that my jacket was taken, and another put in its place.
ROBERT TAYLOR. I found no other jacket on board the ship.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1637.
WILLIAM HOWLISTON
was
indicted for embezzlement .

WILLIAM PRYKE
. I am a baker . The prisoner was in my service from the 25th of March till the 9th of June, when I discharged him; he took out bread and was authorised to receive the money - I gave him the bills on a Monday morning; it was his duty to pay me the money he had received in the afternoon or evening, when he booked his bread.

RACHAEL SEARLES
. I took bread of the prosecutor. The prisoner brought it; I paid him 1l. 5s. 6d., on the 7th or 8th of June: I have his receipt.

JEFFERY FRIEND
. I dealt with the prosecutor, and paid the prisoner 7s. 2d., on the 5th of June; he gave me this receipt.

SARAH FARNAN
. I paid the prisoner 16s. 7 1/2d., on the 7th or 8th of June; I have this receipt for it.

THOMAS VANN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.
WILLIAM PRYKE. He never gave me either of these sums of money.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 29.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Judgment Respited

1638.
GEORGE BURSIL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , 1 coat, value 1l., 1 handkerchief, value 2s., and 1 card-case, value 1s. , the goods of
John Pearce Prangley
.

JOHN PEARCE PRANGLEY
. I live in Bedford-row, and am a solicitor . On the 4th of July I was at Chalk-farm
; I was shooting at some pigeons and sparrows: I took off my coat and gave it to Mr. Greenwood - in the pockets of my coat were my handkerchief, card-case, and gloves: when I had done shooting, my coat and other things were missing - I ran in quest of the man; I found the prisoner in custody: I had not noticed him on the ground.

JOSEPH GREENWOOD
. I was at the shooting-ground. I saw the prisoner there; I gave him the coat to hold, and he walked off with it: I saw him speak to a friend, who was on the ground.
Cross-examined by MR. THOMAS. Q. Were you aware that the prisoner was a friend of that person's? A. Yes, he has know him many years.

GEORGE WALKER
. I was minding horses at the farm. I saw the prisoner, whom I did not know, coming towards the gate, with this coat - I took him.

EDWARD GRAY
(Police-constable S 92). I took the prisoner from Walker; the prisoner had the coat on his arm: the prosecutor has the coat on.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he intoxicated? A. He had been drinking.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he was intoxicated, and that the coat was put into his hands by a person, who the prosecutor had given it to, to hold.
NOT GUILTY .

1639.
JAMES DONNITHORN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 18 shillings, the money of
Edward Palmer
, from his person .

EDWARD PALMER. I am a carpenter . On the 10th of June, between five and six o'clock in the morning, I was at a coffee-stall in the Edgware-road
; the prisoner came by: I had known him before - I had been up nearly allnight; I had been drinking - I called the prisoner, and gave him some coffee, as he said he was very badly off; I then took him to a public-house, gave him something to drink, and gave him a 1s. - I went to sleep and lost 18s. out of my breeches pocket.

CHARLES NAYE
. I called in at the public-house to have a glass of ale; I saw the prosecutor there very tipsy - the prisoner asked him to lend him 1s.; he pulled out a handfull of silver, and lent him one - he then went to the bar, got a pot of porter, and brought it towards him; he then asked the prosecutor for 3d. - the prosecutor was too unconscious to know what he said, and the prisoner put his hand into his breeches pocket, and took out, I should think, 16s. or 18s.; I said to a person, "That young man has been robbed" - they said, "They have been drinking together from five o'clock in the morning, you had better let it alone;" the prosecutor's master came soon after, and I told him to see if his money was right - the prisoner was then gone.

JOSEPH HICKS
. I was coming down the Edgware-road, and saw the prisoner counting some silver into another man's hand, between eight and nine o'clock; he counted 7s. or 8s. - I went on to the Green Man, where they had been; there was an inquiry about it, and I told what I had seen.

GEORGE BIRCH
. I was going up the road, and saw the prisoner on the step of a door, asleep; I awoke him, and asked him to stand something to drink - he said he would see what money he had; he counted out 9s.; we went to the Coach and Horses, and had a quartern of gin, and I left him.

WILLIAM HORSFORD
(Police-constable D 6). I heard of the robbery, and while I was talking to the prosecutor, the prisoner came up; he was drunk - I found 8s. on him, with a loaf, and some other things.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged. 30.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1640.
JOHN BLACKWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , 1 whip, value 10s. , the goods of
William Reeves
.

WILLIAM REEVES
. I am a horse-keeper . I left this whip in a stable at Southall
, on the evening of the 15th of May, and locked the door; the next morning it was gone- the stable was not broken, but there was a place broken, through which some one got in at, and took it out - I had, seen the prisoner the day before; he came to the stable and wanted something of me - I said I could not give him any thing, but I went to the next stable, and recommended him to a person there; this is the whip.

WILLIAM ACRES
. I drive the Richmond coach. The prisoner brought this whip to me; he said he had tried every where, and could not find the owner - I gave him 2s. and a pint of beer for it in the tap-room; I had seen him before.
Prisoner's Defence. I sold it for a man, and gave him the money; he treated me with two pints of beer - I lived at the Star and Garter.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1641.
ANDREW GIBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , 1 pair of watch-cases, value 25s., and 1 seal, value 10s., the goods of
Elias Casper
, his master .
ELIAS CASPER. The prisoner was in my service - I lost this property.

JOHN SANDERS
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in a watch-case from a boy - I cannot say who.

JAMES HARGOOD
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in a watch-case from a boy, who I believe was the prisoner.

THOMAS SEAL
(Police-constable G 145). I had a duplicate of a seal from a man who is not here.

WILLIAM TILLIER
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in the seal, but not from the prisoner.

ALLAN GIBSON
, JUN. I received a duplicate from Malters, and gave it to my father.

GEORGE MALTERS
. The prisoner gave me a duplicate - I did not look at it.

ALLAN GIBSON
. I am father of the prisoner. I received the duplicate from my son Allan, and took out the watch-case - I gave it the prosecutor.
NOT GUILTY .

1642.
THOMAS WHITMARSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 1 pair of trousers, value 4s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
Joseph Chater
.

JOSEPH CHATER
. I live in Clark's-buildings, Bloomsbury, and am a coach-smith . On the 10th of June I was at the Worcester coffee-house, in Broad-street
- I had a pair of trousers tied up in a handkerchief; I placed it on the seat, and went to sleep; it was near two o'clock in the morning - when I awoke I missed my trousers - I went about the street, and met the prisoner in Moor-street; he took off his hat, and took out a handkerchief, which I knew was mine, wiped his face with it, and put it again into his hat - I asked him how he came by it, and said I suspected it was mine, as I had lost one a few hours before; he said it was impossible to be mine, as he had had it six weeks - he refused for sometime to let me see it, but at last he held it up in his hand, and put it into his trousers pocket; I followed him to the Seven-dials, where I got an officer, and gave him into custody; the officer asked him where he lived; he said he had no settled residence - the officer said he would charge him as a vagrant; he then said he supposed I only wanted my property; I said No - he then took us to a house in Castle-street, Long-acre, and knocked at the door; they let him in, and produced the trousers; these are the property - this was about four o'clock in the morning, and about five minutes walk from where I lost them.

SQUIRE WOVENDER (Police-constable F 133). I was at the Seven-dials - I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner; he was given to my charge; I went to Castle-street, and got these trousers.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. On the Saturday night I had no money to pay my rent; I met several young men, who gave me liquor - I got intoxicated; I strolled about till early in the morning, when I met three young men, one of whom I knew; we walked on to Moor-street; they there said they had a pair of trousers they wanted me totake care of - I put them into the house I lodged at; I put the handkerchief into my hat, and went on to the Seven-dials, where I met the prosecutor, who said the handkerchief was his - he then said he had lost a pair of trousers; I said I knew nothing about them, but when the officer came I said I would produce the trousers.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Three Months .

1643.
MARGARET TWIGG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of June , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 seal, value 10s., and 1 watch-key, value 6d., the goods of
John Burn
, from his person .

JOHN BURN
. I am a gas-worker , and live at Kennington. On the 9th of June I was going home, along Bishopsgate-street - I met a person, who is not in custody, she took me to a house in Bear-yard, Petticoat-lane
, and asked for something to drink - a little girl got a pot of beer, and brought me the change; I was then coming out, but the other person caught hold of my arm, and the prisoner pulled me into a back room - the other person then pulled me about, but the prisoner had left the room then; I did not lose any thing while the prisoner was in the room, it was three or four minutes after I lost my watch, seal, and key - I was in pursuit of the other girl with the property, and should have caught her, but the prisoner was in the passage, and got between her and me, and prevented me.
JURY. Q. Were you tipsy? A. No; I had been drinking some rum-and-water.

Prisoner's Defence. This man came with a woman to my house, and begged I would send for something to drink - they got a pot of beer; I then said it was no use to sit there, they must go into the next room - I never left my chair till I heard our door bang; I went out - the prosecutor was coming out of the room, and said he had lost his watch - I said, "Good God! which way is the woman gone?" I ran out, but could not see her.

RICHARD JAMES
PONMAN (Police-constable H 181). I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1644.
WILLIAM SUPPLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
John Charles Litchfield
, from his person .

JOHN CHARLES LITCHFIELD
. On the 10th of June I was in Britannia-fields
, on my way home to Islington, about six o'clock in the evening - I felt a slight jerk at my pocket; I turned, and saw a man who told me my pocket had been picked of a silk handkerchief - I put my hand to my pocket, and missed it; the prisoner was taken.

MICHAEL NEWELL
. I saw the prosecutor walking across the fields, and the prisoner and another walking behind him; I saw the other take the handkerchief, and give it to the prisoner - I told the prosecutor, and I saw the prisoner taken; I am sure he is the person.

ROGER RAGAN
(Police-constable G 147). I produce the handkerchief - the prisoner pulled it out of his trousers, and reached it to a man in the crowd in going to the station - I seized it and put it, into my pocket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A young man pushed the handkerchief into my hands, and said,"Will you buy it?" I was looking where he ran, and the officer took me - I did not know it was stolen.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1645.
JOHN STROUD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 1 waistcoat, value 7s. , the goods of
George Stapleton
.

GEORGE STAPLETON. I live at Brentford
. On the 23rd of June, between ten and eleven o'clock, some persons came into my shop, and asked to look at a handkerchief, and then at some waistcoats; I missed a waistcoat before they left, and when they left, I looked out and saw the prisoner join them, within about fifty yards; I followed the prisoner, and took him with it.

CHARLES WERNHAM
(Police-constable T 169). I received the prisoner in charge; I have the waistcoat, which has the prosecutor's mark on it.
Prisoner. I bought it of a man who travels with articles.

GEORGE STAPLETON
. There was no time between the persons leaving my shop, and my seeing the prisoner for any bargaining about the sale of it; I had seen the prisoner before they came into my shop - I have heard a good character of him.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined One Month .

1646.
THOMAS RILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 9d. , the goods of
Jacob Russell
.

JOHN SAVAGE
. I am in the employ of Mr.
Jacob Russell
, a pawnbroker , in Shoreditch
. On the 14th of June I was in the shop, and missed a silk handkerchief, which had been pinned up at the door, and I had seen safe not more than five minutes before; I received information, and ran up Magpie-alley - I saw the prisoner running up Blossom-street; I pursued, and took him in Gun-street; I said,"I want you, you took a handkerchief from our door;" he gave me this handkerchief, and said he had picked it up.

GEORGE MILLER
. I am a cabinet-maker. I saw the prisoner stopped, and he gave something to the witness.

MORGAN WATKINS
(Police-constable H 3). I have the handkerchief, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw it at the corner of Magpie-alley - I took it up; a woman said it belonged to a boy she saw running, and I ran on.
The prisoner received a very good character.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Seven Days .

1647.
WILLIAM NORTH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of June , 1 shawl, value 3s. , the goods of
Samuel Chass
.

THOMAS HARRIS
(Police-constable D 147.) On the 2nd of June, at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner turn into Cumberland-place, with a shawl in his hand - he ran down Bryanstone-street; I pursued, and asked him where he had got the shawl from - he said he had picked it up.

FRANCES CHASS
. I am the wife of
Samuel Chass
. On the 2nd of June I went to a house in Connaught-square, Edgware-road
- I hung my shawl in the passage leadingto the kitchen; this looks like it, and I believe it is it - that may be half a mile from where the prisoner was stopped; I hung it up about ten minutes after seven o'clock, and it was found about half-past seven.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Connaught-square, and saw the handkerchief by a lamp-post in Seymour-street - I took it.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1648.
ROBERT BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of May , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Shearman Ralph
, from his person .

THOMAS SHEARMAN RALPH
. I am a medical-student , and live in Northampton-square. On the 23rd of May I was walking in Long-acre
; I perceived something strike against me - I felt and missed my handkerchief; I turned, and saw the prisoner pocketing something - I followed him, and when he got to Little St. Andrew-street, he ran; I called Stop thief! and soon found him in custody of Gallaker, who produced my handkerchief.

JOHN GALLAKER
(Police-constable F 120). I took the prisoner, who was running, and quite exhausted - I took this handkerchief from him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going along - the officer came up, and said,"Which is he?" there was a crowd, and a man gave him the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined One Month .

1649.
WILLIAM COLLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 watch, value 30s., the goods of
Andrew Miller
, from his person .

ANDREW MILLER
. On the 17th of June I lost my watch in Coventry-street
, about two o'clock in the morning - I was asleep on the step of a door; I was awoke by two Police-officers, and missed it.

GEORGE BURTON
(Police-constable C 78.) I saw the prosecutor asleep on the step, and the prisoner standing by him - he said he knew him, that he was a friend of his, and he wished to take him home; I tried to arouse the prosecutor - he said he had lost a hat and a handkerchief, but his hat was by his side - I asked if he had lost any thing else; he said a watch - the prisoner then took this watch out of his pocket, and said it belonged to him; I asked the prosecutor if he could swear to it - he said Yes, it was a silver watch, and had a pinchback chain and a key, but no seal.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Was no one else near the prosecutor? A. There was a watchman on the opposite side, and some girls were near the prosecutor, but they went away - the prisoner took the watch from his fob, and said it was his own; he did not put it into the prosecutor's hand - he gave it into my hand - he had been drinking.
ANDREW MILLER. The prisoner was no friend of mine- I had not seen him before; I was drunk.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you remember any girls there? A. No-when I awoke the officer was by; I do not recollect that I saw the prisoner give up the watch - this is my watch; I had not trusted the prisoner with it, to my knowledge - I suppose I went to sleep at twelve or one o'clock.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw the prosecutor on the step of a door, with three girls, and one of them had this watch in her hand; I said, "That is not your watch;" she gave it to me, and they ran down a court - I was ten minutes trying to arouse the prosecutor, and then the officer came; the prosecutor said he had lost his watch; I pulled it from my trousers pocket, and said, "Here it is."

WILLIAM EDWARDS
(Police-constable C147.) I saw the prisoner near the prosecutor - he pulled out this watch, and said it was his own; he was drunk, but knew what he was about - I asked him to go to the watch-house; he said he had no objection - he then said he took the watch from the prosecutor, because no one else should, and he wished to take him to his own house for protection.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, JULY 11.

Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Justice
James Parke
.

1650.
JAMES POTTER
,
ANN POTTER
, and
ANN HILL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 2 bedsteads, value 15s.; 1 feather bed, value 3l.; 1 bolster, value 2s.; 2 paliasses, value 1l.; 1 counterpane, value 1s.; 1 table, value 40s.; 22 chairs, value 3l.; 1 clock, value 5s.; 2 wash-hand stands, value 10s.; 1 knife-box, value 6d.; 6 knives, value2s.; 6 forks, value 2s.; 1 tea-tray, value 1s. 6d.; 1 kettle, value 6d.; 2 decanters and stoppers, value 10s.; 9 pieces of carpet, value 5s.; 1 looking-glass, value 6d.; 2 fenders, value 20s.; 1 tea-caddy, value 3s.; 1 pair of snuffers, value 1s.; 1 snuffer-stand, value 1s.; 6 cups and 6 saucers, value 1s. 6d.; 1 washing-tub, value 1s.5d.; 24 plates, value 1s. 6d.; 1 milk-pot, value 6d.; 5 jugs, value 1s. 6d.; 2 waiters, value 1s.; 1 set of glass cruets, value 3s.; 6 candlesticks, value 2s.; 1 window-curtain, value 4d.; 12 wine-glasses, value 3s.; 4 goblets, value 2s.; 1 pair of tongs, value 6d.; 1 shovel, value 6d.; 3 spoons, value 1s.; 2 basins, value 6d.; 2 teapots, value 3s.; I set of bed-furniture, value 20s.; 3 bonnets, value 6d.; 1 pair of trousers, value 6d., and 1 blanket, value 3s., the goods of
William Evans
, in his dwelling-house .
MR. WALESBY conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM EVANS. I have a house at Enfield-wash, Middlesex
- I left it the latter end of December last, leaving the furniture in it, as when we lived in it - I left nobody in care of it: I bolted and locked every door, and fastened the windows - I think this was on a Thursday before Christmas, but I think not the Thursday before Christmas-day; I returned to my house on the 10th of May, with my sister and four nieces - I found all the furniture entirely taken away, every chair and table, and almost every thing but two or three boxes and a few plates, which were scattered about; I gave information at Worship-street on the following morning; I found the door on the latch - I had left it locked - I judge they had entered from the back part, as the window shutter was open; I went, among other places, to Potters' house, on the 19th -I searched, and found two plated candlesticks on a shelf below, and on looking round I saw many other things which I knew; I went out, and got Wilson - I then gave the prisoners into custody; we searched the house - Wilson took a tea-caddy from the inside of a straw bed, among the straw, other candlesticks, a mug or two, a waiter, and other things were found.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you notgo to the house after Christmas? A. I went past it many times, but did not enter it till the 10th of May, when I went to take possession; my sister was going to remain there for the summer - I saw the curtains up at the window as I passed, but I did not go in - I never employed Potter or his wife.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you know Hill's husband? A. No - I cannot find him; I have eight children - I have a son in trouble: he is the first person I went to when I lost the property; to the best of my knowledge, he is now in prison; I was told yesterday he had been convicted of an offence - he is twenty-two years old; he was at liberty from December to May, and certainly had access to the house; I saw him sometimes - he has been convicted before.

MR. WALESBY. Q. Did you go by your house from time to time? A. Yes - I did not try the door; there are outer gates, which fasten as well - I found the curtains Iorn down on the 10th of May; I had seen them up about six weeks before.

JOHN HOPKINS
. I am a gardener, and live at Godalming now. In December last I lived at Mr. Russen's, Enfield-highway - Evans' house is next door to his; I recollect being at work with John Potter, in Mr. Russen's garden, in March last, and we had occasion to go into Evans' garden: we went close by the house - Jackson, Comfort, and Potter were with me - we went up to the house, and looked in at the back window; we were taking night-soil from Russen's premises, and having some ale; I was leaning against the shutter, and took hold of the pin accidentally, and turned it round - to the best of my knowledge the inner pin fell out; I took out the bolt, opened the shutter half way, looked in, and saw some crockery-ware in the kitchen, and think I saw two gridirons, but it was dark in the kitchen; I saw Potter look in at the same time, but he said nothing - I left Mr. Russen on the 9th of April.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Are you sure there was an inner pin to fall out? A. Not certain. I put the bolt in as I found it; the window was not open.

JAMES HANLEY
. I am an officer of Worship-street. On the 11th of May the prosecutor gave me information of this robbery, and on Sunday morning, the 20th, about five o'clock, I went with him to Potter's cottage, in Swins' - buildings, Enfield; I found a pair of trousers, a pair of tongs, poker, and shovel - I went to Evans' house, examined it, and found no marks of breaking outside, but the door of a room up stairs had been forced with a chisel apparently - I went about seven o'clock the next morning to Hill's house, and found up stairs a bed, a mattress, nine chairs, a mahogany wash-hand stand, basin, a jug, a knife-box, three pieces of carpet, a dish, a bonnet, a tea-board, two knives, two forks, a grid-iron, some white bed-furniture, and other articles, which Evans claimed - I saw Potter in the cage at Enfield, on Friday, the 20th of May; he made no confession to me.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Who told you it was Potter's house? A. I saw Mrs. Potter there.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. The chairs and beds must be some weight? A. Yes, Hill's wife appears near her confinement.

RICHARD WATKINS
. I am a horse-patrol of Bow-street. On the 21st of May I went to the office, as Potter was coming out from being examined, with Abbott, a constable; I did not make him any promise, or threat, nor did any body in my hearing.

GEORGE ABBOTT
. I am a constable of Enfield, I was at the cage on Monday, the 21st of May; Potter was in my custody - I did not threaten him, or make him any promise; he said it was a bad job that had happened, and he was very sorry for it - I had taken him between seven and eight o'clock on the 19th of May; I had not told him the charge; Wilson and Evans were both with me - Evans had given him in my charge at his own house at Enfield-wash; he said it was a bad job, and that some of the furniture he had bought down in the country of a person, a table, and other things - on Monday, the 21st, I took him to the office, and in the morning he was taken there again; Evans and some of the furniture were brought up, and I took him to the cage again - he said at the watch-house that there were four in it, and that was all- he did not mention any names.

RICHARD WATKINS
re-examined. As the prisoner returned from the office to the watch-house, he told me it was a bad job; I asked was there any one in it besides him and Hill - he said, "Only the women;" I asked, "What women" - he told me their names: he said Hill and him would never have done it, if they had not been persuaded by the two women, their wives - I judge that he was speaking of the robbery.

JOHN WILSON
. I am a constable of Enfield. I went to Potter's house on Saturday, the 19th and found a bed, a mattress, ten chairs, a mahogany chair, two candlesticks, a vinegar and pepper-cruet, and other things, which Evans claimed.

SARAH SWIN
. I live at Enfield-wash. I know both the female prisoner's; Hill came to my house in April, and offered to sell me a pair of decanters, which she did for 7s. - I gave them to the constable.

ELIZA EKINS
. I live at Enfield-wash. I went to Mrs. Hill's house in April, with some things to be washed - she said she had a wash-hand stand, and brass fender to sell for Mrs. Prosser; I told her I would send my father to look at them - she said I must not let him come, because she owed Mrs. Swin some rent, and if he came to look at them, she might put a distress into the house, thinking something was going out.

WILLIAM EKINS
. On Saturday night, the 12th of May, Mrs. Hill brought a fender and wash-hand stand to me; I bought them of her.

SARAH PROSSER
. I live at Enfield-wash. I never authorised Hill to sell any thing for me.

JOHN MEAD
. I am a constable of Enfield I received these decanters from Swin; I searched Hill's house, in company with Hanley and Wilson, on Monday, the 28th of May.

HANNAH PIKE
. I live at Enfield-wash. In May last I went to Hill's house, and saw Mrs. Hill; she offered me some broken things in a basket, to throw away for her - I did not see them; I went again the same Sunday afternoon, the 20th of May, and saw a chair burning on her fire- I saw part of the leg, and the cane bottom; she told me she had burnt the greater part of the bed-furniture, and other things.

MR. EVANS. These things are all mine; the property found at Potter's is worth more than 10l. - near 40l. worth was lost; I think the premises were entered from the back window, near Mr. Russen's privy - it was shut when I went there; I do not know whether it was fastened - the street door was on the latch, and the pin was out of the shutter; the property might be removed at different times.

WILLIAM GARNER
. I live just on this side of the Bell, at Enfield-wash, and am a hay-carter; I know Swin's-buildings - I was out with my cart about three months ago, and met two men and two women; the women were almost close to me - I did not know them; it was hardly day-light - they appeared to be carrying luggage; I could not discern what it was.

J. POTTER -
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

A. POTTER -
NOT GUILTY .

HILL -
NOT GUILTY .

1651.
THOMAS WHITTARD
was indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Ann Nichols
, on the 26th of May
, and stealing 1 shirt, value 15d., her property .

ANN NICHOLS
. I live in Goldsmith's-row, in the parish of Shoreditch
. On Sunday morning (I cannot say whether it was one or two Sundays before Whitsuntide) I missed this shirt, which I had put into a box on Thursday morning - the prisoner lives next door to me; he was in custody early in June at his mother's house, and I heard him say, voluntarily, that he had pawned the shirt at Mr. Harris', Hackney-road - he said he got in at my back window; I cannot say whether that was open or shut.

JOSEPH HEWETSON
. I am shopman to Mr. Harris, a pawnbroker, Hackney-road. This shirt was pawned on Saturday, the 26th of May; I believe the prisoner to be the boy.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 12.

1652.
THOMAS WHITTARD
was again indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Ann Nicholls
, on the 2nd of June
, and stealing 1 gown, value 5s., and 1 pinafore, value 1d., her property .

LUCY NICHOLS
. I live with Ann Nichols, my mother. I put this gown on a basket one day between ten and eleven o'clock, and missed it between nine and ten at night- I had brought it from the pawnbrokers.

THOMAS EAGLES
. I apprehended the prisoner on Sunday morning, the 3rd of June, and told him it was for stealing something from Mrs. Nichols, his next door neighbour; he said, voluntarily, that he had pawned the gown at Miller's, in Kingsland-road, for 1s., and that he got into the house, by the back window - I examined the house; the casement seems as if it had been left open, and there is nothing to prevent a person getting in.

EDMUND SUTTON
. I am servant to Mr. Miller, of Kingsland-road; I have a gown, pawned by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 12.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1653.
THOMAS EGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 100 yards of bed-ticking, value 10l., the goods of
Matthew Faulkner
, in his dwelling-house .
The prisoner had obtained the goods by a false representation, which did not amount to felony.
NOT GUILTY .

1654.
MARTHA KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 2 gowns, value 30s.; 1 shawl, value 1l., and 1 pencil-case, value 1s. , the goods of
Harriet Hawkes
.

HARRIET HAWKES
. I am servant at the British and Foreign Club-house, Piccadilly
. On the 2nd of July I went out, about half-past three o'clock, and left these articles in my bed-room - I was sent for at half-past five, and went to Queen-square.

EMMA BUNCE
. I live in the same house; my husband is a groom. On the 2nd of July I was in the kitchen, and saw the prisoner go up the area-steps - I followed and overtook her, about two hundred yards off, with a bundle - I asked her to return with me, to No. 105, Piccadilly - she said she was going a little further, and would return bye-and-bye- I said I wished her to return immediately; she said she could not think what the housekeeper wanted with her -I said she would tell her when she got there; when we got to the corner of Dover-street, she said, "Take the bundle, let me go," but did not offer to give it to me - she went and towards Hyde-park - I pulled her back, and got a Policeman, who took her with the bundle - she said she had come and there for a person named Bennet, who she washed for, who owed her some money - nobody of that name lives there - the bundle contained these articles.

DAVID JONES
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner detained by Bunce, she said "Take the bundle, and let me go" - I took her into custody.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 42 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1655.
BARNETT BENJAMIN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, of an evil-disposed person, 4 shirts, value 1l., the goods of
James Gibbs
, well knowing them to have been stolen .

JAMES GIBBS
. I live in Holywell-lane, Shoreditch
. On the 16th of March my house was broken open - I lost a set of black silk handkerchiefs, four shirts, and other articles.

FRANCES GIBBS
. I am the prosecutor's wife. The four shirts were produced by the officer; I know them to be my husband's - the house was entered through the brickwall; my initials are on the shirts now.

ALEXANDER MITCHELL
. I am a surveyor of the Thames Police. On the 17th of May I searched the prisoner's house, in Playhouse-yard, Golden-lane - he keeps a clothes shop; he was not at home; I found on the shelf, in the shop, a bundle, containing some shirts, four of which Gibbs claims; I did not see the prisoner till the 22nd of May, when he came to the office; I asked if he kept the house; he said Yes, and had done so for thirty years.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

1656.
ELLEN LESLIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 9 yards of ribbon, value 12s., the goods of
James Newton
and another .

THOMAS HUNT
. I am shopman to
James Newton
and
John Evans
, linen-draper s, Leicester-square
. On the 30thof June the prisoner came to the shop, and asked to match a piece of gros-de-naples, which I informed her we had not got; she returned in twenty minutes, to match some ribbon - I showed her the box - she took a piece from the box and looked at it - a customer came in at that time, for when I cut off four yards of ribbon, and on turning back to the prisoner I missed a piece of Petersham ribbon, it being the only piece we had of the colour and quality - I did not like to accuse her of it, but went to the top of the shop, and told Bauer that I missed it; he came forward to look for it- we had a general search for it - I moved the box off the counter, and made the counter clear; the prisoner was then accused of stealing it, and on Bauer's touching her pocket-handkerchief the ribbon fell from it: but previous to that I saw her take the ribbon from her pocket in front, and wrap it up in her handkerchief, which she put on the counter - she had her pocket-handkerchief out when she was looking at the ribbons, and had looked at that Petersham ribbon, and taken it in her hand, having her handkerchief in her hand at the time.

Q. Had she a pocket in front? A. She had; I observed her take something from that pocket into her handkerchief - it must have been the ribbon; and then she placed her hands, with the handkerchief, on the counter, and when her handkerchief was touched the ribbon fell out - she then said she had taken it by mistake - we did not accuse her of stealing it, till after I saw her take something out of her pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not, at first, say you saw her take the ribbon out of her pocket? A. I did, that was a mistake - she took something, and it must have been that; she had her handkerchief in her hand when bargaining for the ribbon, and put it down before her- we did not search for the ribbon above a minute or two after I saw her take her handkerchief from her pocket - she had said, before I went to the other customer, that that Petersham ribbon was not exactly what she wanted, but as I had no other, that must do - our shop may be about forty feet long; I left her at the counter while I went to the end of the shop, to tell Bauer - she was about three yards from the door - there was nothing to prevent her leaving, as far as she knew.

COURT. Q. Was it before you spoke to the young man that you saw her take something out with the handkerchief? A. After; she had taken that ribbon in her hand once to look at - I do not know whether she returned it to the box; I am sure she took something, out of the pocket, put it into her handkerchief, and held the handkerchief before her.

Q. When did she say she would take that ribbon, as you had no other? A. I said I had a piece in reserve, which I would go and get (as an excuse to go to the young man), and then she said if there was no other, that would do - she had her handkerchief in her hand before she put it into the pocket - I cannot tell whether one or two hands went into the pocket; the handkerchief was in both hands - I moved them both down to the pocket.
JURY. Q. Was the pocket tied round her, or in an apron? A. It was under her dress; there was an opening in her dress in front - it is such a pocket as is worn at the side.

WILLIAM BAUER
. I am in the prosecutor's service. I was at the other end of the shop; Hunt spoke to me - I came forward to notice the prisoner - she was sitting down before the counter; I watched her movements, and told Hunt to search the ribbon-box behind the counter -I saw her pocket rather fuller than is usual in front of a ladies' dress, and saw her moving her hand about in her pocket, but whether she took any thing out I cannot say; I saw her take her handkerchief from her knees, where she had laid it, and put it on the counter, still keeping it in her hand - I touched the handkerchief, and the ribbon dropped out; I charged her with taking it - she said she had taken it by mistake; I sent for an officer; she requested me to let her go, but as my employer was not present, I was obliged to act as I thought proper.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say the handkerchief was on her knees? A. Yes, she sat with it in her hand on her knees - there were two young men between her and the door, but perhaps she might have gone out without difficulty; the ribbon is a good size; I saw her put her hand into her pocket, but will not swear she took any thing out - there was an opening in front of her gown, and the pocket went down to her side - there were more valuable ribbons in the box.

THOMAS HUNT
. This is the same ribbon as she had been wishing to buy - she had asked for no particular quantity then, but before she had asked for three-quarters of a yard - 1s. would pay for that.

GEORGE SPINDELOW
. I am a constable. I received the prisoner in charge, and took her to the station; a woman searched her there, and found this piece of silk, one or two shillings, and a few halfpence in her pocket - she said she had taken the ribbon from there, and was very sorry, but it was done quite by mistake, and if money would make it up she would get money, and if I would let her speak to the prosecutor, she had no doubt he would make it up.
Cross-examined. Q. The ribbon does not match that silk? A. No.
Prisoner's Defence. I took it by mistake - I am a native of Liverpool, and have no friends in town.
NOT GUILTY .

1657.
GEORGE MANN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Liddell
, from his person .

JOHN LIDDELL
. On the 26th of June I was in Ball-alley, Shoreditch
, and lost a silk handkerchief from my pocket - I was stooping at the time, and did not perceive it taken.

CHARLES PACKER
. On the 26th of June I was standing at my father's door in Ball-alley; the prosecutor was stooping; I saw the prisoner, with another boy; the prisoner took the handkerchief from Mr. Liddell's pocket, put it into his bosom, and walked down the alley with the other boy - I told Liddell, and then went and asked the prisoner for it; he said he had not got it, but I saw it hanging out of his bosom, and took it.

GEORGE DAVIS
. I am a headborough. I received him in custody with the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Week .

1658.
SAMUEL MAYCOCK
and
JOHN JENNINGS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , I live tame rabbit, price 2s. , the property of
James Summers
.

JAMES SUMMERS
. I am a plumber , and live in Quaker's-gardens, Kensington
. On the 23rd of June, at five o'clock in the morning, I missed two rabbits from the garden behind my house; I had not seen them since the 22nd, at noon I had three more; they were in hutches, which were closed; when I went in the morning one was left in the hutch which the two were taken from.

WILLIAM BRAIN
. I live in Stingo-lane, and deal in rabbits. On the 23rd of June the prisoner came and offered to sell me three young rabbits, and an old one; I bought them of Maycock, and paid him for them - I cannot say who brought them; I gave 4s. for the four - Jennings took no part in the bargain; they both came in, and Maycock spoke first.

JOHN POINTING
. I am a Policeman. On the 23rd of June, I took the prisoner's at Fulham-bridge; I turned them out of a yard; Jennings had 4d.: there was a boy named Perryman with them - after they got to the watch-house, Jennings told me they had sold the rabbits in Stingo-lane, and divided the money between the three, which was 1s. 4d. each.

Cross-examined by MR. WALESBY. Q. Where is Perryman? A. He was not committed; he had no basket - Jennings did not say, in his presence, that he had a share of the money.(Property produced and sworn to)

Maycock's Defence. Between eight and nine o'clock in the morning I met this young man and Perryman together; Perryman asked me to buy a rabbit; I said No, but I would tell him where to sell them - we all three went together; I went in to ask the man if he bought rabbits - he said Yes; we took them in, and sold them.
Jennings' Defence. I met the prisoner in Queen-street; he asked me to buy a rabbit - I said No.
Jennings received a good character.

MAYCOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Confined Three Months .
JENNINGS - GUILTY. Aged 14.

Judgment Respited
.

1659.
WILLIAM MEATYEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 12lbs. of veal, value 5s. , the goods of
John Thomas Miller
.

ANN BARTON
. On the 23rd of June I was in Spitalfields-market, and passed Miller's stall; I saw a man take a fillet of veal - he turned round by Mr. Gregory's greenstall; I only saw his back.

SAMUEL MILLER
. I was servant to
John Thomas Miller
, a butcher . I was standing inside the shop at the corner of South-street
, and saw the prisoner with a bundle in his apron, ten or twelve yards from the shop; the Policeman took him.

JOHN BURROUGH
. I am a Policeman. I was in the market, and saw Miller running after the prisoner, who was secured, and as I took him to the station, he threw away a fillet of veal; I got possession of it, and showed it to Miller.

JOHN THOMAS MILLER
. I am a butcher. I saw the prisoner at the corner of South-street; the Policeman took him - I knew the veal to be mine, by the cut; I missed it from my shop.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in the market looking for work - I wanted bread for my wife and four children; a man asked if I wanted a job, and said he would give me 6d. to take the meat to the Nagg's Head, Whitechapel, and he would be there, as soon as me.

GUILTY . -
Confined One Month .

1660.
WILLIAM BRIAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 3 pairs of shoes, value 12s. , the goods of
John Crispin
.

JOHN YOUNG
. On the 6th of July I saw the prisoner run from Mr. Crispin's shop door, with some shoes in his hand - he had more than one pair; Crispin came out, and gave an alarm - the prisoner kept on, and turned up the first street; I lost sight of him, but afterwards saw Crispin bring him back.

JOHN CRISPIN
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Tottenham-court-road
. On the 6th of July, at night, an alarm was given - I ran out, and followed the prisoner, calling Stop thief! till a man stopped him; I found nothing on him - as I returned, I saw three pairs of shoes picked up by Hill, in the direction he ran; they were mine - I had seen them in my shop less than an hour before; he was not out of my sight.

JOSEPH STANNARD
. I took the prisoner in charge -Hill delivered me the shoes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never had them.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

1661.
ALLEN CHARTERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 bridle, value 5s., and 1 pad, value 3s. , the goods of
William James
.

ABRAHAM JAMES
. I live in Russell-mews
with my son William, who is a livery-stable keeper - the prisoner was in his employ about eight months ago. On the 29th of June, about half-past six o'clock in the morning, when I went into the stable, he was there, and asked how I did; I said, "I don't know you;" he said, "Yes you do, I worked here for your son some time ago;" I said, "I have no knowledge of you;" he said, "He told me he had a set of harness for sale;" I said, "I know he has not, for his harness is in use;" he said, "This is the harness with the lion on it;" I said that was not for sale, for it was a glass-coach harness; he unbuckled the pad; I went up stairs to speak to my son, who was asleep, and when I came down he was gone, with the bridle and pad; I found him about a week after, and asked him about it - he said it was not sold, but he knew where it was; I asked him to give me the address where it was - he said he would not; he did not say it was in pledge; I afterwards found it at a pawnbroker's, in Seven-dials.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not take the bridle and pad, and put them on my arm? A. I did not; I never said I would not prosecute you if I received 8s.

JAMES ALDOUS
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 29th of June a pad and a bridle were pawned by the prisoner; I have known him twenty years.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am a Policeman. I received him in charge last Thursday night - he said he would returnthe harness in the morning, or 2l. 10s.; he produced the duplicate of it.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I called upon the prosecutor's son - he asked me to sell the harness; the prosecutor himself gave me the articles laid in the indictment, to show to hackneymen, to see if I could dispose of them, but being extremely old, although I had tried to sell them, I could not succeed; being very much distressed and fatigued, I called at Mr. Aldous, in Berwick-street, Soho, and pledged them for 1s. 6d., fully intending to redeem them, and return them to the owner - after I had received them from the prosecutor he wished me good-day, saying, that he had no money to treat me, and I said neither had I any.

- WILLIE. The prisoner sent for me the evening he was taken, and I saw Mr. James, who said to me,"God bless my soul! I don't think the man has taken it with intent to steal it;" I said, "I believe he has not;" he said, "Will you call on me?" I called that evening at his place - he then said he did not think he took it with intent to steal it and not bring it back, but he did not bring it back for a week, and he was afraid his son would make him pay for it; I said I would make a bridle and pad to match rather than he should be taken - he said, "Well, I think I would take 8s. and drop it, if my expenses are paid;" I said as I had known Charters so long I did not mind that.

ABRAHAM JAMES
. I never saw the witness but once till he was before the Magistrate; I did not tell him I believed the prisoner did not intend to steal it, nor offer to make it up for 8s. and my expences - he followed me about from time to time, and wanted me to go and drink with him; since I have been here he has also followed me about.
NOT GUILTY .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1662.
HENRY BRANDT
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .

JOHN THOMAS
. I am a mariner . I came home on the 20th of November -
Alexander Ross
, of Pennington-street, owed me money for wages; I went for it on the 20th of February, and he offered me 20l. - the prisoner came to my lodging at No. 27, Brook-street, Ratcliff
