, about that time; I did not know him before - a woman, who lived in the house, was telling him how I was served by Ross, and the prisoner sent for me up to his room, which was on the second floor - he said he would take it in hand to get the money for me, if I would give him the money to pay the law-fees; I thanked him, and told him I would well reward him for it; we went the next day to what he called the Crown Court - I do not know where he it is; it was nearer to St. Paul's than to Whitechapel - I there gave him three half-crowns and 2s. 6d. to pay the law charges; I saw him again the same night, and a good while after; he said he was going on, and would soon bring Mr. Ross too and make him pay the money; I went with him to a place where there were a great many people, and gentlemen with whigs on, but I always waited outside - he always desired me to keep outside while he went in; he was to recover 26l. for me - he said he was an Excise-officer; I never saw him again for a long time after I gave him 2s. to buy a stamp: I have not seen Ross since - the prisoner showed me a Bank-warrant, and said he had 500l. in the Bank - he went into the Commercial-road to buy the stamp, and told me he would bring me the money next day, but I saw no more of him.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not lodge in the same house as you? A. Yes; we both lodged at the house in Brook-street - I never lent you any money, and never said you had paid me 1l. 4s. 6d. of the money I lent you; I never sent a note to you in Newgate - I cannot write.

BOYD SILVESTER
. I am an officer of Thames-police. The prosecutor made a complaint at our office against Ross, for detaining his money and clothes, and complained of the prisoner about the beginning of June: I was sent with the prosecutor to see where he gave the prisoner the money; what he calls the Crown-office, where he paid 10s. is the Excise-office, which is in the City.

JANE EVANS
. I live in Joseph-street, St. George's East: Thomas lost a good deal of money which he had left with a publican; I heard the prisoner say he was an Excise-officer, and would forfeit 500l. if he did not get him the money from Ross: that was three or four months ago; he said he could not get it without going to different lawyers in the City, and every time he went he wanted money from Thomas - I saw Thomas give him some money in my room; I then kept the house in Brook-street.

Prisoner's Defence (written) I was an English prisoner in France, and belonged to the ship Prosenjine - I took a lodging in the same house as the prosecutor; I paid some money to him off the debt I owed him - when the officer took me to the Thames Police-office, he stated that he heard the prosecutor say I had paid him part of the money back; when the clerks heard this, they discharged the Policeman, and gave me into the charge of a Thames Police-officer.

JOHN THOMAS
. I showed Silvester where I paid him the 10s.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1663.
GEORGE HITCHCOCK
was
indicted for perjury .
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1664.
FREDERICK BENNETT
was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 pair of of trousers, value 18s., the goods of
Thomas Sharpe
and others .

WILLIAM TALBOT
. On the 7th of July, a little before twelve o'clock, I was in the shop of
Thomas Sharpe
and others, tailor s, Worship-street
, and saw the prisoner snatch these trousers down from about a yard within the shop - they were pinned on an iron; he ran away with them in his apron - I pursued and took him with them, without losing sight of him.

WILLIAM HOMES
. I am a Policeman. I received him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1665.
SAMUEL CUSHION
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , 1 watch, value 10s. , the goods of
David Moses
.

The watch being the goods of David and
Samuel Moses
, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1666.
JOHN CARR
was
indicted for embezzlement .

SECOND COUNT, for stealing 1s., the money of
Daniel Connel
.

DANIEL CONNEL
. I am a cow-keeper , and live in Hackney-road. On the 19th of June the prisoner was employed by me to cart bricks from Messrs. Rhodes', whose country house is in Balls'-pond
- I did not send my account in for a week after; I do not know how much was due, as the prisoner gave me a false account - he used to tell me every day what work he had done, and I settled with Messrs. Rhodes every Thursday; on Wednesday morning I gave him the account to take to them - he was not to receive the money; I was to call for it next day, but I did not call till the Thursday week, and finding I had no money to receive, I gave him in charge - he said he had received 8s. 4d., and that was all; that was one day's work - he said he had bought a pair of half-boots with the money, and would pull them off his feet if I would forgive him; he had received one week's wages, and had 5s. advanced towards the next.

JOSEPH BANKS
. I am junior clerk at Messrs. Rhodes. The prisoner carted bricks for us; he asked for employ in the name of Laig, and did not say he was the prosecutor's servant - on Thursday, the 21st of June, I paid him 8s. 4d. for one day's cartage; Mr. Connel applied for it on the 28th of June - here is the receipt the prisoner gave me.

RICHARD HAWKES
. I received the prisoner in charge - his master asked him for the account which he ought to have delivered to Messrs. Rhodes; he then gave me the account, and said he had received the 8s. 4d., and bought a pair of half boots with the money.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

1667.
JOHN FISHER
was indicted for
stealing on the 26th of May , 3 gallons of turpentine, value 13s. , the goods of
Thomas Green
.

GEORGE NORRIS
. I am a shopman to Thomas Green, an oilman , in Little Bath-street, Clerkenwell. On the 26th of May, about eleven o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came to the shop, and ordered three gallons of turpentine, to go to Mr. Powell's, Lower Islington - I sent it by Miles, who was to bring the money back - the prisoner went with him; he took it in two cans, which came back empty.

JOHN MILES
. I am in Mr. Green's employ. I was sent with the prisoner with three gallons of turpentine, in a cart, which I had the care of; the prisoner said it was to go to Mr. Powell's (Lower Islington
, and when we got to Powell's), as the prisoner called it, he asked me to wait outside, while he took the turpentine into Powell; I gave it to him, out of the cart, which stood on the opposite side of the way to Powell's, who is an oilman - I saw him take it in; he brought the cans out, and said Mr. Powell would not have the turpentine - he set the cans on the pavement, and said he would go to another customer, and see if he would have it; just after he went, the cans were opened, and contained nothing but oil of tartar - I never saw him again till he was taken; I am sure the cans contained turpentine when I gave them to him.

JAMES FRITH
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Green. I saw the turpentine put into the cans; the prisoner drove the cart, pointed out the shop, and told us to wait opposite - he came out once or twice, and said Powell was busy, and kept us waiting half an hour; he then brought out the cans full of pearl-ash and water, which is called oil of tartar - I thought there was something wrong, and opened them immediately; I pursued, but could not find him.

WILLIAM RODD
. I sell pies in the street. I was passing Powell's, in Lower Islington, and heard Powell halloo out Stop thief! and saw the prisoner running - I pursued, and he was taken; Powell told me a young lad had given charge of him about some turpentine - he said nothing to that; this was about a month after the transaction.

FRANCIS FEATHERSTONE
. I am a Policeman. On the 28th of June I saw Rodd pursuing the prisoner, and stopped him - he was charged by Powell's boy with stealing 9s. 6d. - this charge was made at Worship-street.

THOMAS GREEN
. Oil of tartar is about 3d. a gallon - the turpentine cost me 4s. 3d. a gallon; Powell was held to bail with the prisoner on this charge.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, JULY 11.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1668.
THOMAS TROWER
was
indicted for bigamy - To which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1669.
ANN BRYANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 1 gown, value 14s. , the goods of
Catherine Door
. - To which she pleaded

GUILTY . -
Confined Three Months .

1670.
HENRY WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Robert Hitchcock
, from his person .

ROBERT HITCHCOCK
. On the 26th of June I was walking, with my brother, about half-past nine o'clock in the morning, in Regent-street
. A gentleman behind us said, "That person crossing the street has picked your pocket;" at the same moment, my brother exclaimed, "Somebody has picked your pocket - we crossed the way;" I saw the prisoner, and seized him - he had rushed between us and the wall, as we thought very rudely; this is my handkerchief.

ROBERT STONE
. I saw the prisoner pick the pocket - he then crossed the road - the gentleman seized him, and he threw the handkerchief down.

WILLIAM HACK
(Police-constable C 34) I took the prisoner.
Prisoner. I hope you will have mercy upon me.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1671.
EDWARD GROOME
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June
, 3lbs. of pork, value 2s. , the goods of
John Goodwin
; and
CHARLOTTE GROOME
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen .

JOHN GOODWIN
. I am a pork-butcher - Edward Groome was in my service. On the 27th of June I sent him to my stable, and soon afterwards I missed my little girl; I went to the stable to see if she was there, at half-past one o'clock, and I was surprised to find the stable doorshut - I looked in, and saw the two prisoners there; the girl was wrapping something in a cloth or apron - the boy was walking from her, towards the door, and seemed very much alarmed - I asked who he had there; he said his sister, who had come for his dirty linen - I asked what she had; she said her brother's dirty linen; I opened the bundle, and found this piece of pork, which is mine - the stable is down a mews, about five minutes' walk from my house.

E. GROOME -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

C. GROOME -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.

1672.
JOHN BURGIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 5 brushes, value 6d. , the goods of
James Banks Harraden
.

WILLIAM BLAIN
. I was in Islington-road
on the 30th of June; I saw the prisoner and two others loitering about the prosecutor's house - I watched, and saw him lean over a rail and take the brushes off a nail, outside the shop; he put them into his apron, and ran away - I pursued, and took him with them.

JAMES GODFREY
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner.

JAMES BANKS HARRADEN
. These are my brushes, and were taken from my shop.
Prisoner's Defence. Another boy gave them to me.

GUILTY . Aged 12. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1673.
JOHN BOWLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 1 watch, value 30s. , the goods of
Benjamin Holley
.

BENJAMIN HOLLEY
. I am a sweep . The prisoner was employed by me on the 23rd of June; I left him in bed, and my watch was in my bed-room; when I returned it was gone - I found him on the Brentford road; he was secured.

JAMES ALDOUS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Berwick-street, Soho. I received this watch from the prisoner on the 23rd of June, in the name of
John Bowles
.

HUGH SANDILAND
(Police-constable T 80). I took the prisoner, and found the duplicate on him.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1674.
JAMES CULLENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 pair of shoes, value 10s., the goods of
Michael Elbell
, from the person of
John Elbell
.

JOHN ELBELL
. My father is a shoemaker . On the 27th of June I was carrying some shoes home - I stopped at the corner of Titchfield-street
, and the prisoner snatched them from under my arm; I called Stop thief! but he got away, and the shoes have not been found - he was taken in four days afterwards; I had seen him about the street with a butter basket.

THOMAS LOCK
(Police-constable S 35). I took the prisoner at the Hare and Hound tavern.
Prisoner's Defence. He was playing at buttons, and put his bag on the step of a door - he then missed the shoes, and he knew no one but me to charge with it.
NOT GUILTY .

1675.
ELIZABETH CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of May , 6 pence and 14 halfpence, the monies of
George Green
, his master .

GEORGE GREEN
. I keep a general shop - the prisoner was in my employ for three months, as servant of all work . I missed some money; on the 20th of May I marked 13s. worth of copper, and put it into my till - I went out as usual on Sunday, from eleven till one o'clock; when I came back I found the till had been opened, and missed 1s. 1d.; I taxed her with it; she denied it - I got an officer, who was about to search her, and she produced seven 1d. pieces, but none of them were marked; I asked if she had any more; she denied it - she was taken to the station-house, and 2s. 4 1/2d. was found on her; two halfpence and three 1d. pieces were marked, and were what I had put in my till.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Was not she in the habit of paying for little articles? A. No; she had no more right to go to the till than a stranger had.

THOMAS CALLOWAY
(Police-constable H 79). I took the prisoner, and Francis searched her.

SUSANNAH FARNCIS
. I serched the prisoner, and found on her two half-sovereigns, eight half-crowns, some small silver, and 2s. 4d. in copper - some of it is marked.

GEORGE GREEN
. This is the money I marked.

GUILTY . Aged 60. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1676.
PETER DAVIDSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 3 sovereigns, the monies of
John Neale
, from his person .

JOHN NEALE
. I am a servant - I have known the prisoner between two and three years; I believe he is a groom . On the 24th of June I had been out with him drinking - he was out of place; I went home with him to another man's lodging - I pulled off my coat and my boots, laid down on the bed, and went to sleep; it was then about one o'clock in the morning - I was sober; I had a purse in my fob, containing three sovereigns - I awoke between seven and eight o'clock in the morning; I found my clothes were all unbuttoned, and my braces undone, which I had not done myself - I felt, and thought I had lost some silver from my pocket; I then felt my fob, and thought the three sovereigns were safe, but I found afterwards that they were three shillings - I did not give any alarm, but asked the man who keeps the room permission to go to the water-closet; the prisoner said he would show me the way - when I was there I examined my purse, and found they were only shillings in it; I went up again, but said nothing to the prisoner; we then went out together, and the first officer I met I gave charge of him.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Had not the prisoner asked you to go to give bail? A. No; he asked me to go with him to a Frenchman, to speak on behalf of two women and a man, for robbing a man at a public-house; I had drank with the prisoner the night before - we began about ten or eleven o'clock, and left off about twelve; I was not drunk - I did not ask him to take care of my money; I was capable of taking care if it myself.

ROBERT CULLY
(Police-constable C 95). The prosecutor charged the prisoner with stealing three sovereigns from him; he denied all knowledge of it, but as the prosecutor persisted that he had, I took him to the station - he then said he had taken them for safety, and he had left them at a person's house, where he went to procure bail; Isearched the house which he described, but could not find it - I then went back to the prisoner, and made him strip; I found this money concealed in the lining of the back of his waistcoat - he then said he took it, but did not know where he had put it.

Prisoner's Defence. He was intoxicated: he asked me to have something to drink; we went to a public-house, and had three glasses of liquor - we then went to another public-house, and drank there till half-past one o'clock in the morning; we then went to a person's house, where he laid down, and was ill.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

1677.
RICHARD FLEMING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 watch, value 5l., the goods of
Joseph Ellis
, from the person of
Sarah Ellis
.

SARAH ELLIS
. I am the wife of
Joseph Ellis
. I went to the review in Hyde-park
, on the 26th of June - I was standing against the rails, and felt something move my pocket; I turned, and caught the prisoner, who was close to me, by the coat; he ran - I followed him, and cried thief! I caught and held him till he put his hand into his side pocket, and gave my watch into my hand - this is it; it had been in my right-hand pocket; I gave him into custody.

WILLIAM HOOKER
(Police-constable D3). I took the prisoner - he said, "You are quite mistaken;" I took him to the lodge - he then said, "I am sorry for what I have done, I hope you will look over it - I have lately been married."

JANE HORNBUCKLE
. I heard the prisoner say, "Here is your watch, I took it."

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1678.
WILLIAM GODBELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, and 3d., in copper, the monies of
Walter Pitman
, his master .

WALTER PITMAN
. I am a boot-maker . The prisoner was in my service for about a month - I missed some money, and on the 22nd of June I marked some silver and copper, put it into my till, and went out of the shop to get my breakfast, leaving the prisoner and the shopman there - I returned in about ten minutes, and found the till had been opened; I took the shopman and the prisoner, and accused them of it; they were desirous of being searched - when the officer came the prisoner took the money from his pocket, and said I have only 1s. 9d. about me, which my mother gave me last night; he was stripping to be searched- I said that is the money I lost, and the officer took him.

RICHARD SHEPPERD STEVENSON
(Police-constable S 165). I took the prisoner, and have the money, which is marked.
Prisoner. The money was marked after he found it on me.
MR. PITMAN. No; it was not.
GUILTY. Aged 12.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Whipped and Discharged.

1679.
ROBERT PURTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
James Thompson
, from his person .

JAMES THOMPSON
. I hold a situation in the Bank. On Sunday, the 1st of July, I was at Holborn-bars
, at a quarter before twelve o'clock at night - I felt my handkerchief taken - I turned, and seized the prisoner with it in his hand; I gave him to the officer, but I saw him run from him, and I held him till the officer came up again and took him - I understood the officer had been knocked down and had lost the handkerchief; and while I stood there I was surrounded by thirty or forty bad characters.
Prisoner's Defence. I was ten yards from the gentleman when he took me, and I was ill-used by the Policeman.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1680.
JAMES SUDDY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 necklace, value 10s., the goods of
Samuel Tunnicliffe
, from the person of
Rachael Tunnicliffe
.

THOMAS LOVEDAY FAIRBRASS
. I am in the service of Mr.
Samuel Tunnicliffe
; he lives in Sydney-street, Commercial-road
. On the 23rd of June, his daughter, Rachael, was in the kitchen, and had her necklace on - she went up to the door, and I heard her cry out that she had lost her beads - I went up, and saw the prisoner about five yards off. I took the child in my hand, and took the prisoner - she said, in his presence, that he was the man who had taken the beads; he said he knew nothing of them; but when the officer took him he acknowledged taking them, and giving them to another man, and said if we would go with him he would let us have them.

MORRIS CASEY
(Police-constable K 216). I took the prisoner; he said if we would go with him, to where he lived, he would give up the beads.
Prisoner's Defence. I was five or six hundred yards off when I was taken.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Months .

1681.
MARY SMITH
and
ROSINA SAVELIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 1 pair of boots, value 10s. , the goods of
William Moore
.

THOMAS LOUGHBOROUGH
. I am in the service of Mr.
William Moore
; he lives in Upper King-street, Bloomsbury
. On the 29th of May the prisoners came with another person, and asked to look at some shoes; it was some time before I could learn which of them wanted them; at last Smith took a chair, and I got two or three pairs for them to look at; they said they were not what they wanted; they went away, and I missed a pair of men's boots; I went in pursuit; they were all walking together, two doors from my shop; I told Mr. Moore of it, and left him to mind the shop while I went after the prisoners - I found them in a passage in Southampton-row, standing out of the rain - I requested them to come back, saying I had missed something - they said they had stolen nothing, and would not come back: the other got away; but I took the two prisoners back. Savelin dropped the boots from under her arm, in Green-street - I had just sold them, and laid them on a chair, to go home.

PETER KENDALL
(Police-constable E 89). I took the prisoners; I found only 1d. on them, and a duplicate.

The prisoners put in a written Defence, stating that they had gone with
Mary Ann Brain
, who wished to buy a pair of shoes, and she had taken the boots in question unknown to them, but they had never been in the possession of either of them.

SMITH. -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

SAVELIN. -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1682.
MARY SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 1 pair of studs, value 12s.; 1 ring, value 8s.; 1 ear-ring, value 8s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 snuff-box, value 1s., the goods of
Robert Brock
, from his person .

ROBERT BROCK
. I am a jeweller . On the 23rd of June I went from my house in Spencer-street, early in the morning, with the property stated in my pocket; I met the prisoner in Shadwell
- she was alone and asked me to give her something to drink; I went into a public-house, and gave her some gin - she then forced me up a court, into the house of another girl, and took the property from me; I tried to extricate myself, but could not: she put her hand into my trousers pocket, and took out the studs and rings - she took the snuff-box from my waistcoat pocket, and the handkerchief from my coat pocket; as soon as I could see a Policeman, she ran off, and threw the handkerchief to the other girl, who ran off, but the prisoner was taken - I was drunk, but knew what I did.

WILLIAM CRICK
(Police-constable K 255). I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner together in Shadwell, High-street for some time; the prosecutor told me he had been robbed of all his property - I asked if he wished me to take the girls; he said, "Yes, I have asked them to give up the property, and they will not:" they were walking till they saw me, and then they ran off - I saw the prisoner throw a handkerchief to another girl, who has got off.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1683.
SARAH WICKS
and
ANN HARDING
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of June , 1 purse, value 1s. 6d., and 17 sovereigns, the property of
John Purnell
, from his person; and that Wicks had been before convicted of felony .

JOHN PURNELL
. I am a mariner . On the 20th of June, I had been up all night, but was sober; I was looking after a sister of mine, and met the prisoners about half-past three o'clock in the morning: I do not know in what street I first saw Harding - she asked me to have something to drink; I said it was too soon: there was another girl with her, but Wicks was not there then - they then asked me to have some coffee and bread and butter, which we did; I was coming away, but they followed, and took me into a private room - I staid there an hour and a half, but had nothing to do with any of them; Harding then went out, and brought in Wicks: Harding said she was her sister, and asked if I did not fancy her - I said No, I did not fancy either of them; I got up and went out - the prisoner's followed me to a public-house, where Wicks took my purse out of my pocket - Harding was close to her at the time; I had seventeen sovereigns in my purse: Wicks ran off with it - I followed, and Harding stopped me, and said she would come back, that she was sky-larking - I have never got the purse since; the officer took Harding; Wicks was taken three days after.

GEORGE HUSTWAYTE
. I saw Wicks take the purse out of the prosecutor's pocket, while he was drinking a glass of ale; she went out of the public-house instantly - he followed her, and Harding followed him.
Wicks. When the prosecutor was leaving the house, he was asked if he had all his money right, and he said Yes.

JOHN PURNELL
. Hustwayte said, to me, "You will be done," and I said, "I am wide awake."

THOMAS PRENDIVILLE
(Police-constable 140 G). The prosecutor told me he was robbed, and I took Harding at the time.

GEORGE DOSSON
. (Police-constable G 123). I took Wicks from the prosecutor's description.

MICHAEL GLADWELL
(Police-constable G 162.) I have a certificate (which I got from Mr. Clark's office) of the conviction of Wicks; she had three months imprisonment in the House of Correction; I took her, and know she is the person.

Wicks' Defence. I met Harding, who asked me to go to the room with her; I saw the prosecutor on the bed, with his clothes undone - he said, "Come, and I will give you all something to drink;" we went and had something to drink at the public-house - I then came away directly; I was not near him - there were two more girls in company.
Harding put in a written Defence, stating that she had left the prosecutor for some time, and after she returned he complained of being robbed, but being innocent, she did not attempt to escape.

WICKS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

HARDING -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1684.
SUSETTA SOLOMONS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 25th of June , 11 books of sheet gold, value 16s., the goods of
John Davison
, well knowing them to have been stolen .

JOHN DAVISON
. I am a bookbinder . I have an apprentice named
Thomas Tonge
; I never authorised him to sell any of my property - I never saw the prisoner till I was at the office; my gold was going quicker than it ought to go, and I was about to make a complaint to the man who used it - I cannot swear to this gold, but I had property of this description.

THOMAS GEORGE TONGE
. I am apprentice to the prosecutor, and had been with him about three months - I secreted these books of gold in his shop, and took them away without his knowledge: I took them on Monday evening, the 26th of June, to the prisoner, Mrs. Solomons (I had been there once before with a gold ring) - when I got to the shop I saw a boy there; I asked for Mrs. Solomons, and the prisoner came down stairs, preceded by another lady - I asked if they would buy the gold; they made no answer, but the other lady took the books of gold from me, and began rubbing it out of the books into the scale with her finger - Mrs. Solomons either asked the boy for a knife, or took a desert knife and scraped it into the scale - two young men then came to inquire about a brooch - they made some remark, and left the door open; Mrs. Solomons then called out,"Shut the door;" when they were gone the other lady asked if it was not half a crown a penny weight they gave for the gold - Mrs. Solomons made no answer, but sent the boy out for change; I do not know what I was to get for the gold - I was taken into custody at the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How old are you? A. About sixteen; I was at Mr. Wace's before I was turned over to my uncle, Mr. Davison - I had never stolen any thing before this; my uncle had not told me he had missed property before this; Mrs. Solomons' is a refiners shop - I had been there before, and sold some rags for Mr. Wace,and gave him the money; I assisted in turning out these books of leaf gold - some of it did fall about; I had not turned any out before Mrs. Solomons came down - Mrs. Solomons took a knife or a spatula, and turned it into a bit of paper, and then put it into the scale; there was no price asked for it - if there is a wind, leaf gold will blow away; she desired the door to be shut - I did not hear the boy say that; I did not hear the prisoner say that Mr. Solomons must be sent for - when the boy came back with the change, she the officer was in the shop, and then the prioner said "Is Mr. Solomons coming;" I was then taken up.
COURT. Q. Your master did not know you were going there? A. No.

JOHN McLEOD
. I went to the prisoner about a brooch; I saw the book of gold then, and the witness was turning the gold into the scale - I said it was a curious way of transacting business, and I went away; Green was with me.

CHARLES FREEMAN
(Police-constable C 71). I was on duty, and met Green and McLeod; I went to the prisoner's shop - I saw her and another woman there, and the witness; I asked how he got that gold - he said he had been sent with it by his master, or an errand boy had been sent for it, who had crumpled it up, and they could not use it, and his master sent him to sell it; Mrs. Solomons had a spoon or a knife scraping it out - it is not all out now - it was nearly nine o'clock at night.
NOT GUILTY .

1685.
JOHN CAIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas George Thompson
.

THOMAS GEORGE THOMPSON
. I am a bosier . On the 27th of June, about ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came into my shop, in the Haymarket ; he asked to look at some handkerchiefs, which were shown to him - I watched him, and saw him double one up in his hand, and run off with it; I pursued, and forced him into the lobby of the opera-house, and this handkerchief was found on him, in my presence.

EDMUND COX
(Police-constable C 114). I took the prisoner; he gave me the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY. Aged 20. -
Judgment Respited
.

1686.
JOHN DYE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of June , 3 handkerchiefs, value 7s. , the goods of
Joseph Thimbleby
.

WILLIAM SAUL CALVER
. I am in the employ of Mr.
Joseph Thimbleby
, he lives in Old-street-road
. On the 18th of June, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner snatch down these handkerchiefs, which were hanging between the door and the window - I ran out, and saw him putting them under his apron; when he saw me, he threw them down, and ran - I pursued and took him.

GUILTY . Aged 9. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1687.
ROBERT FIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 3 pairs of boots, value 8s., the goods of
John Giles
and another .

RICHARD BOWERY
. On the evening of the 27th of June I saw the prisoner and another near Giles' shop; the prisoner had come shoes in his hand - I went up to him; he said, "Don't say any thing" - I took hold of him, and he dropped them; I took him into custody, and told Mr. Giles.

WILLIAM GROVE
(Police-constable C 157). I took the prisoner, and have the property.

JOHN GILES
. I have one partner; these are our property.

GUILTY . Aged 9. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1688.
TIMOTHY GALLON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 counterpane, value 18s., and 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Job Cable
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

JOB CABLE. I let a ready furnished room to the prisoner about two months back; he occupied it six or seven weeks - he was behind in the rent. On the 28th of June my wife saw him go out with a large bundle; she had suspicion - we waited till half-past ten o'clock at night, when he and his wife came home; I then sent my wife up to inspect their room - she missed a counterpane and sheet - I spoke to an officer at the door, who took the prisoner, and found the duplicate.

NATHAN BARNES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, which was pawned by the prisoner.

GEORGE JOHN MOULTON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a counterpane, which I believe the prisoner pawned.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ROBERT GROVE
. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office. I was a witness on his trial, and know he is the man.
Prisoner. I should have had some money in a short time, and should have replaced the things on Saturday night.

GUILTY . Aged 47. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1689.
JOHN HUMPHRIES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 2 gowns, value 6s. , the goods of
Catherine Leonard
.

CATHERINE LEONARD
. I am single . I had my box at the prisoner's mother's, in Poland-street
, on the 25th of June; it was locked, and was safe on the Sunday - On Monday I went - it had then been broken open, and the gowns were gone.

JOHN BARTLETT
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a gown, which was pawned by the prisoner.

THOMAS HOBBS
(Police-constable C 85). I took the prisoner; in going along, he met a relation, and said to him, "Go tell my mother to make it all right;" and the next day I received this other gown from a young man, who said he brought it from the prisoner's mother.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was out of work, and I took these gowns to get some tools, thinking they were my mother's.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Three Months .

1690.
WILLIAM JONES
and
JOHN THOMPSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 waistcoat, value 5s. , the goods of
William Plant
.

THOMAS FARRANT
. I am a Police-constable. I was in Oxford-street
, on the 26th of June, between five and six o'clock in the evening; I saw the prisoners, and watched them - I saw them go to the prosecutor's door; Thompson stood looking in, while Jones took out two or three pins from the waistcoat, and took it down - I took Thompson, and Rice took Jones, with the waistcoat.

WILLIAM RICE
. I took Jones, and took this waistcoat from under his coat.

WILLIAM VIVIAN ROE
. I am shopman to Mr.
William Plant
. This is his waistcoat, and was on the rail at his door.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

1691.
RUTH LOVETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of June , 1 spoon, value 3s.; 1 pair of sugartongs, value 5s.; 1 gold chain, value 3l., and 1 ring, value 12s. , the goods of
Ann Cofield
.

ANN COFIELD
. I am a widow , and live in Lincoln's Inn-fields
; the prisoner was my servant for a fortnight. On the 11th of June I went out to Lambeth, and while I was gone, she stripped my place; I have seen some of my things since.

BENJAMIN CATMULL
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner in Shoe-lane at a quarter before nine o'clock, on the 11th of June; she had received a very bad cut from a fall, and being in liquor, I was taking her to the watch-house - a tea-spoon dropped from her; I set her down, and saw a bundle in her bosom - I took it out, found an old purse, these silver-tongs, and a gold chain; I then thought I heard something drop, and picked up this gold ring; I found three sovereigns on her person.

ANN COFIELD
. These are mine. I lost a great deal more.

Prisoner's Defence. I lived with her a fornight, and she came home drunk every night, with a mob about her; she sent me to a woman to tell her fortune - these things were not taken with a design to rob her, but to return them to her before a witness.

GUILTY . -
Confined Twelve Months .

1692.
SOPHIA HORDER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July, 18 yards of ribbon, value 10s., the goods of
Richard Hodge
and another; and three net-collars, value 30s., the goods of
Edward Parry Jones
.
To which she pleaded

GUILTY. -
Judgment Respited
.

1693.
GEORGE MONEYLAWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of June , 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 towel, value 8d.; 1 basket, value 2s., and 6 lbs. weight of beef, value 4s., the goods of
James Ramage
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

THOMAS FARRANT
(Police-constable C 42). On the 21st of June, at nine o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner in Brewer-street, carrying something in his apron - I followed, and asked what he had got; he said a piece of linen, to make himself an apron - I took him to the station, and found the prosecutor, who claimed the property.

JAMES RAMAGE
. I am a tailor , and live in Little Compton-street
. These are my property, and were taken from my kitchen - I do not know the prisoner.

JAMES RICHARDSON
. I am pot-boy at the Duke of Argyle. On the 21st of June I saw the prisoner in the tap-room, with the parcel.

THOMAS HOBBS
(Police-constable C85). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office - I know he is the man.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the things in Clothfair, and intended to make myself an apron.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1694.
MARY NICHOLLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , 1 decanter, value 3s. , the goods of
John Wrigglesworth
.

ALBERT MARTIN
(Police-constable N 72). On the 3rd of July I met the prisoner at the end of Shoreditch - she bad something concealed under her apron; I thought it was something she ought not to have - I pursned, and asked what it was; she said a bottle which had been given to her, but she did not know by whom; I said she must go to the station, and on the way there she said it was given her by her mother, who had borrowed it the day before, to get some wine, as she was ill - I at last found the prosecutor.

JOHN WRIGGLESWORTH
. I am a publican , and live in Shoreditch
. The prisoner was in my house that morning, and when she was gone I missed this decanter from my sideboard.
Prisoner's Defence. It was given me outside the door.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1695.
THOMAS NUNN
and
THOMAS PRIDHAM
were indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 16th of June , 1 pair of trousers, value 2l., the goods of
John Lloyd
, well knowing them to have been stolen .

THOMAS ANDERSON
. I am in the service of Mr.
John Lloyd
, a tailor , of Conduit-street
. On the 16th of June he gave me a bundle, containing a pair of trousers, to take to Mr. Pontifex. at Holloway - there was a direction on the parcel, but I cannot read or write; Mr. Roberts put it on - I was looking in at a picture-shop in Oxford-road, and the prisoner Nunn spoke to me; I did not know him, but he asked why I did not make haste on with my errand, and if my master was at home; I said No - he said he had lived with Mr. Lloyd for thirteen months, and he had taken three waistcoats and a coat to Holloway - he walked with me as far as Portland-place, and then he left me; he had looked at the direction on the parcel - after he had left me some time, Pridbam came up, and asked if my master was at home; I said No - he then asked where I was going: I told him - he gave me a halfpenny, and told me to make haste there; I went on to Camden-town, and then another person came to me; he asked whether I lived at Mr. Lloyd's; I told him Yes - he then asked if the things I had were for Mr. Pontifex, at Holloway; I said they were - he said he came from there, that Mr. Pontifex was waiting for them, and he wanted to be measured for some more on Monday - he took the parcel, gave me 1d., and when he got some distance form me he told me he would give me 6d. on Monday.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How far had you got after you spoke to Pridham, before you saw the third person? A. A good way - I did not see what was in the parcel; the housekeeper gave it to me.

GRIFFITH ROBERTS
. I am clerk to the prosecutor. I packed up the parcel containing the trousers, a blackfrock coat, and a waistcoat, and put on it the direction" Wm. Pontifex , Esq., Holloway;" Anderson was to take it - Nunn never lived with Mr. Lloyd.

JOSEPH MYERS
. I live in Princes-street, Soho. On the 16th of June, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was standing at my door to tell the Policeman to call me up in the morning, and saw the two prisoners coming from Leicester-square towards my shop; Nunn had a bundle, with a white cloth covered over it; he said to the other, "You go and beef, and I will go and lumber them" - he gave to him what appeared to me to be a waistcoat; Pridham then crossed the road, and Nunn went on to a pawnbroker's - I, knowing they were bad characters, went to lay hold of Pridham, but he ran down a street, and I thought if I followed him I should lose the other - I then went back to the pawnbroker; I just heard the pawnbroker say, "I can't take them in, it is too late," meaning a pair of trousers - I laid hold of Nunn, and said I should detain him, for having stolen these trousers - he said, "Where did I steal them?" I said, "No matter;" I took him out - I cannot be mistaken in Pridham's person, because I was in Clerkenwell prison at the time he was.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You never saw a pair of trousers with Pridham? A. No - I think I was eight days in Clerkenwell prison; I have not been in any other prison - I am a pencil-maker by trade; I was in the Police for thirteen months, and had several prisoners here - I never had any charge against me; I was reported for being too late, and was fined 1s. - I was dismissed for taking a placard from a person with the word "Reform" on it, near the House of Lords; the Commissioners thought I ought not to have interfered with it; that was the only reason why I was dismissed - I was fined twice; I was in prison for having some drugs without the stamp on them.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How often have you given evidence in this Court? A. Six or seven times.

ELIZABETH STROUD
. I am Nunn's sister. He brought me, on the 16th of June, a pair of trousers and silk waistcoat, which he had bought, and wanted me to lend a sovereign on them.
THOMAS HOBBS (Police-constable C 85). I went to Stroud's, and got these trousers.

THOMAS FARRANT
(Police-constable C 42). I was in the office when the trousers were first brought in -Stroud came, and said they were her husband's; Nunn was liberated - I afterwards received information; I went, and took Nunn again - I asked where the woman was; he said he did not know - I locked him up, and went with Hobbs to Stroud's, and got the trousers again; I afterwards got information, and took Pridham.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Nunn's Defence. I was sitting in the Globe public-house, and a man called me out at a quarter-past eight o'clock - he said he had a pair of trousers for sale; he owed me 6s., and I gave him 16s. more for them - I took them to Stroud's, and wanted her to lend me a sovereign; she said she could not, but she would pawn the trousers for me and a black silk waistcoat of my own; she took them, but did not get enough - I told her if she could lend me the rest of the money I wanted, I would pay her, but she could not; I then went, and got them out again - I went to the other pawnbroker's, where I was taken; the man I had them of is a tailor.
Pridham's Defence. I know nothing at all about it.

NUNN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

PRIDHAM -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1696.
HENRY ROWLAND
was
indicted for embezzlement .

JOHN WEBSTER
. I am a cheesemonger . The prisoner was my porter for eight or nine weeks; he was not authorized to receive money on my account.
NOT GUILTY .

1697.
MARY NEALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1s.; 2 watch-keys, value 4d.; 1 seal, value 6d.; 1 box, value 4d.; 1 sovereign, 2 half-sovereigns, and 5 shillings, the property of
Thomas Pearce
, from his person .

THOMAS PEARCE
. I am a labourer , and live in Oxfordshire, but was in town on business. On the 23rd of June, about ten o'clock at night, I met the prisoner - I do not know in what street it was; she asked me to go home with her - I agreed to go; we went to a public-house, and had a quartern of gin, and then went to a room; I gave her 1s. 6d. for the room, but had no concern with her - I was tired, and fell asleep; when I awoke the prisoner was gone, and my money, watch, and box; the officer took the prisoner in a few minutes - I know she is the person.

THOMAS HAINES
. I am an officer. On Sunday morning, at half-past two o'clock, the prosecutor said he had been robbed - he was then getting nearly sober; I went in search of the prisoner, and found her; I had seen her with him at half-past ten o'clock - she denied all knowledge of the property, and said it was not her, but another girl.

THOMAS ARNOLD
(Police-constable D 32.) I assisted to take the prisoner - she objected to be searched by a man, and I was going to send for a woman; at last she said a married man should search her - I then untied the string of her apron, and this box fell on the ground; I took it up, and said, "What is in this?" she said, "Only a shilling;" I opened it, and found two half-sovereigns: she said, "Take one of them, and say no more;" I said,"We don't do business in that way;" I then untied the string of her flannel petticoat, and this watch fell down.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor at half-past nine o'clock, and he gave me the watch; he was very drunk - I never looked into the box at all; I only went to the next door, and he called the officer.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1698.
MARTHA SADLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 seal, value 15s., and 1 watch-key, value 5s. , the goods of
Charles Collins
.

CHARLES COLLINS
. I live in Hyde-place, Islington
. -The prisoner lived next door but one to me, and sometimes called to speak to my wife - I had a gold seal and watch-key in a drawer in my bed-room, and on the 28th of June they were gone; I had seen them safe the day before.

GEORGE CLARK
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in this seal from the prisoner.

JAMES MARLOW
. I am a pawnbroker. I took this key from the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had found the articles on the prosecutor's step.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Confined One Month .

1699.
JAMES SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of June , 1 gown, value 2s. , the goods of
William Hunt
.

WILLIAM HUNT
. I keep a beer-shop in Drury-lane
. -On the evening of the 19th of June the Prisoner came; he went into the parlour, and called for a pint of Burton ale; I said I had not any - he wanted me to go into the cellar, and tap a barrel; I said I could not - I then went to speak to a friend in the shop, and saw him at the cupboard behind the door, and I thought, concealing something; he then went out, and got about two hundred yards - I went after him, brought him back to my parlour, and he pulled this gown out of his hat, which he had rammed in so that he could hardly put it on his head - he threw it on the floor; he seemed sober.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1700.
MARY SHANNON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 frock, value 2s., and 1 pair of boots, value 4s., the goods of
George Barclay Barrett
, from the person of
Robert Barrett
.

GEORGE BARCLAY BARRETT
. I live in Crown-court, Soho
. My son Robert is five years old; he was playing about my place on the 25th of June, and we did not know he was away till a woman brought him back; he had a frock and a pair of boots on when he went out, and when he returned they were gone.

ANN BONNER
. I live in Bainbridge-street; my mistress lets out beds. On the 25th of June, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, the prisoner, who was a stranger came to the house; she brought a little boy , and wanted a bed: the little boy was dressed, and had a pinafore on - she did not mention any thing about him, but asked how much the bed would be; I said half a bed would be 4d. - she said show me the bed, which I did; she paid the 4d.: she then asked me to go for some gin, and gave me 2d. - I went, leaving her and the child there, and she was giving the child some strawberries; when I came back the child was coming, crying, down stairs, and the prisoner was gone - I was called on the next day to see if I could tell the prisoner.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was it not getting dark? A. No; my sight is pretty good: the prisoner had a red shawl on, a white straw bonnet, and a light linen gown, which seemed rather dirty.

ELIZABETH KINGSBRIDGE
. I am ten years of age, and live with my father in Little Pulteney-street. I was in Soho-square, between seven and eight o'clock, on the day before I went to the Magistrate; I saw the prisoner there with this little child - I said, to him - "Babby, where are you going?" the prisoner said she was going to give him a pottle of straw berries - he was dressed then; the prisoner is the person who was with him; she had a red shawl on and a white bonnet.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you not say, she had a black gown, a black bonnet, and a white apron? A. No, she had a blue apron; I do not know whether I said she had a black gown, and a black bonnet - I think I did, and I think she had them on; I told the Magistrate so: I said she had a white bonnet on, because the last witness said so.

FRANCIS BEDFORD
. I am a jeweller, and live in Carlile-street. On the evening in question, I saw the child at twenty minutes past seven o'clock; I knew the child, and to the best of my belief, the prisoner was with him - she had hold of him, or he had hold of her; they were going towards Soho-square.
Cross-examined. Q. Will you tell how she was dressed? A. She had a white straw bonnet, and a red shawl on.
Prisoner's Defence. It is quite false.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1701.
ANN THOMAS
and
JANE LLOYD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , 1 quilt, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Nicholls
.

GEORGE CHAPMAN
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Thomas Nicholls, a pawnbroker , in Gray's Inn-lane
. On the 3rd of July the prisoners came to the shop; Thomas came to take out a pair of stockings - I let her have them; Lloyd had come and asked the price of a quilt the day before, and on this day they asked to look at it; Thomas then took the stockings, and went away, telling Lloyd to wait till she came back - she came; they staid some time, and then went away: I then missed the quilt - I had known them before; I found where they lived, and went with an officer to their lodgings - I found Thomas in the room, and this quilt on the bed; Lloyd was in the room over it - I had not seen either of them take the quilt; this is it.

RICHARD BAYLIS
(Police-constable G 67). I went and asked Lloyd what she had done with the quilt - she said she knew nothing of it; that it was in the room below: I went and found it in the room where Thomas was.

Thomas' Defence. I went to get the stockings, and picked up this quilt; I took it home, and it laid there an hour or better - he then came and said it was his master's; I said I did not know, he could have it if he pleased; he said No, he would not, he would send for an officer.
Lloyd put in a written Defence, denying that she was aware of the theft.

THOMAS -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Three Months .

LLOYD -
NOT GUILTY .

1702.
BENJAMIN WHEEDON
was indicted for
stealing. on the 21st of June , 4 pairs of leather soles, value 3s. , the goods of
John Sladden Harvey
. - To which he pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1703.
WILLIAM WILLIS
was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 glazed window-sash, value 1l. , the goods of
James Wheeler
.

PAUL PLANT
(Police-constable G 156). On the 27th of June, at five o'clock in the morning, I was in Ball-alley, Goswell-street
; I had had information that some sashes had been taken from there - I heard somebody say, "Get down, or some one will see you;" I spoke to my brother officer, and he went round another way - I went down the alley, and found a door ajar; I pushed it, and it opened(it had been fast before that) - I went in, and saw the prisoner in the parlour, and another person in the corner; I challenged the prisoner, and asked what he did there - he said, after some time, that he had been on a drunken spree; I said I thought some other business had brought him there - I went to the door, but could not get assistance; the prisoner came to the door, and said he was a young man like myself, and if I would let him go, I should not find him there again - I waited till a man sent the watchman to me; I told him to go into the house with the prisoner - I heard a noise, and went in - I saw the watchman on the floor, and the prisoner making a blow at him; he then got out - I pursued him, got assistance, and secured him; I found this bar in the corner, where I had seen the other man stoop down.

JOHN EASTOFF
(Police-constable G 189). I went to the house, and found this knife on the window-seat; this sash had been taken out, and stood there.

SARAH SPRAGUE
. This house was empty; it belonged to Mr.
James Wheeler
- I had been in it the day before, and it was all safe.
Prisoner's Defence. I sat down on the door side, and being tipsy, I got into the house, but did not take any thing away, nor see it, till I was at the office.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1704.
LOUISA WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , 2 half-crowns, and 3 halfpence, the monies of
James Beckett
, from his person .

JAMES BECKETT
. I am a shoemaker . I met the prisoner in Brick-lane
at half-past ten o'clock at night, on the 24th of June; I was sober; I went with her, and gave her a quartern of gin - I took out 6d., and paid for it; I had then two half-crowns, and three halfpence - we went out together, and I felt her draw her hand from my left-hand waistcoat pocket; I accused her of stealing my money: she said I was a liar; I called the Policeman - she then denied it again; she was searched, and the money found on her.

JOHN GREEN
. (Police-constable H 91). The prosecutor accused the prisoner of robbing him; she denied it till she got to the door of the station - she then said she had robbed him, and would return the money; I found one half-crown, and three halfpence in her bosom - the other half-crown she gave from her pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I met him; he asked me to have something to drink - we then came out, and he wanted to know if he could go home with me; I said No, not to where I lived - he then asked me to go some where else; I said I did not mind - we went; he told me to go into the house first, and gave me this money.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1705.
DANIEL BRYANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Robert Passmore
, from his person .

ROBERT PASSMORE
. I live in Orange-street, Bloomsbury, and am a book binder . I was returning home on the 17th of June, and was in Whitechapel
- I had passed the church, and Savage gave me information; I felt and missed my handkerchief - I left a lady who was with me, went after the officer, and met him with the prisoner; this handkerchief is mine - it was produced to me; it had had J. E. on it, but part of it had been taken out - it had been given to me by an acquaintance.

WILLIAM SAVAGE
(Police-constable H 50). On the 17th of June I was in Whitechapel, about half-past three o'clock - I saw the prisoner and four others - he was close to the prosecutor; I saw him quit him, and run off - I spoke to the prosecutor, and then ran after the prisoner down Essex-street; I saw him put this handkerchief into his pocket - I pursued him into Wentworth-street, and from there to George-street; I observed the corner of this handkerchief out of his pocket - I stopped him in George-street, and took it from him; he said he had picked it up - I then met the prosecutor, and he claimed it; the prisoner sells wood in Whitechapel; I never knew any harm of him.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1706.
ANN ROGERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 2 silver spoons, value 5s.; 1 napkin, value 1s.; 3 dusters, value 1s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 basin, value 2d.; 1 glass, value 1s.; 3lbs. of tea, value 12s.; 8lbs. of sugar, value 6s., and 6lbs. of soap, value 3s., the goods of
James Edward Mivart
, her master .
MR. CHURCHILL conducted the prosecution.

JAMES EDWARD MIVART
. I keep an hotel in Brook-street, Grosvenor-square
; the prisoner was in my service. On the 6th of June I missed some articles - the officer was sent for; her box was searched, in my presence - a quantity of tea and sugar, some dusters, napkins, two silver spoons, some bars of soap, and a cut glass were found, some of which I can swear to; there were a great many more things, which I could not swear to.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Can you swear to the tea? A. No; I can swear to the spoons - this basin matches the rest I have; it is full of sugar, and just as it was taken: the pattern is peculiar - these cloths have my name on them; she said they were master's property - she came into my service about a year and a half ago; I had no quarrel with her - I have found some fault with her about the business of the house; I never put my first in her face - I have a person named Frogget in my service; she has not been dismissed - she went away for a short time, on account of ill-health; I certainly never told the prisoner not to mention any thing that passed between me and Frogget; nothing improper ever took take place - the prisoner would not give up her key till the officer came, and told her to consider herself in custody.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I am an officer. The prosecutor sent for me; the prisoner went up stairs and consented to have her boxes searched - she then made some objection, but when she was given into my custody she opened a cupboard, and gave the key of her box, in which were these articles, which have been in my care ever since- she said these dusters and the napkin were her master's, but the tea, sugar, and other things were not.

Cross-examined. Q. She acknowledge these dusters and napkin belonged to her master? A. Yes, and the glass and basin, but not the other things, nor the spoons; she said she could produce others like them.

MR. MIVART. I believe these to be my property - theprisoner was my housemaid; she could not have any of the silver spoons properly, nor this breakfast napkin, nor this cut glass, which was sent up with tea.

Prisoner's Defence. I waited on the nurse, morning and evening, and she gave me a small portion of tea and sugar, which I put into my bonnet-box; there was a lady who had her breakfast carried up to her - I put the napkin into my box, to use in mixing the tea, the black and green together; I had bought a great part of the tea to send to my mother, and the sugar also - the silver spoons are my own- my master knows that the lady was in No. 17 room, who had her breakfast in bed.

MR. MIVART. Her mistress was to take the breakfast to that lady, and these things were found in the floor over the one that lady was on - there were 20 lbs. or 30 lbs. of tea found in her box; the tea and sugar nearly filled a large clothes-basket.

- ROGERS. I am the prisoner's mother. I gave her two spoons, ten or eleven years ago - there was an S. on them, and I believe these are the spoons; I had another daughter - on her marriage the prisoner gave her these spoons; her husband died, and then I took my daughter home, and all she had - she died, and I gave the spoons a second time to the prisoner; I live at Wetherford, forty miles from London; at chance times the prisoner has sent me a little tea and sugar, or thread or cotton - for my own use, I do not sell them.

COURT. Q. Upon your oath, do you believe these to be the spoons which, eleven years ago, you gave to your daughter? A. Yes, I do - the prisoner gives me tea and sugar sometimes, and sometimes I send her a trifle of money for it.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. What was the name of your daughter who died? A. Mary Selwin - she died three or four years ago; the prisoner has sent me a pound or a pound and a half of tea, not more.

GEORGE LEE
. I am a waiter. I called on the prisoner about three years ago, and drank tea with her, in company with a female; it was at a broker's shop in Gray's Inn-lane, where the prisoner then lodged - my friend asked the prisoner if the spoons were what her sister had; I saw two silver spoons there of a plain make, and they had an S. on them in rather a large cypher - they were much worn.

COURT. Q. How came you, three years ago, to take particular notice of two silver spoons? A. It was in consequence of my friend's remark - my friend's name is
Eliza Baker
; I believe she lives in the City-road - I have not seen her lately; I had no acquaintance with the prisoner before then - I have seen Baker since the prisoner has been in custody; I was told to come here on Friday or Saturday last - Baker is not here.

MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Have you had any acquaintance with the prisoner since the time you speak of calling on her? A. No; I saw Baker about three weeks ago - I had not seen her more than two or three times since I went with her to the prisoner - she lives in Britannia-street.
MR. MIVART re-examined. Q. Had the prisoner an allowance of tea and sugar? A. No; they found their own - these were old spoons, which I bought some years ago.

ANN MARY OTWAY
. I was in the prosecutor's employ twelve months ago - the prisoner lived there at the time; I saw her have two silver spoons with an S. on the handle - I remarked them, because Mr. Mivart had some spoons belonging to the housekeeper's room, with the same mark on them, and I told the prisoner if Mr. Mivart saw them he would say they were his, as they were exactly like them; I said that because the prisoner brought them down for us to have tea, and they might be mixed with others.
COURT. Q. Did not Mr. Mivart supply you with spoons? A. No; I have bought metal spoons myself, and we found ourselves tea and sugar, and cups and saucers.

CAROLINE ARGENT
. I now live in Thanet-place, Strand I did live at the Rainbow coffee-house, which my aunt kept - the prisoner was in my aunt's service; I knew her - I met her in Farringdon-street one evening in March last; I asked where she was going - she said to a place, and she had been purchasing some tea at Ludgate-hill - I saw a paper parcel in her hand which looked like tea; she said she had three week's holiday, having been ill.

MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How large was the parcel she had? A. I do not know, it appeared rather large - I am not in the habit of buying tea, we have it sent home, but I never see it; I never saw a pound of tea sent home in paper.

JANE GRIFFITHS
. I live in White Lion-street, Pentonville - the prisoner called on me in March, and brought a parcel of sugar with her; I went out with her, and bought 3lbs. or 4lbs. of tea in the City.

COURT. Q. Where was she living at that time? A. She said she was in the service of Mr. Mivart - I was going to Farringdon-street myself, and I said I would go as far as the tea-warehouse with her; I went with her to Twining's - she then went with me to Farringdon-street, and I paid the interest on a bed; we then went to my house in Chiswell-street, and had tea - she then gave me something less than 1 oz. of tea, and took the rest home; I do not know where she had bought the sugar -I think there were 6lbs. or 7lbs. of that; she paid for 3lbs. or 4lbs. of tea - she put down a sovereign; I do not know what change she had.
MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Was the sugar tied up? A. Yes, in a white handkerchief - she said it was sugar; the tea was in two papers - I am not sure whether she had any change.
COURT. Q. What priced tea did she ask for? A. I think 7s. green - I am not sure what the black was; I paid attention to the change - I think she had about 3 lbs. of tea.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY of stealing the tea and sugar only. Aged 29.
Recommended to mercy, believing she took it in small quantities, when it had been left by the company .
Confined Six Months .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1707.
SIMON FRANKLIN
and
MARY ANN FRANKLIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 bed, value 1l.; 1 bolster, value 4s.; 2 pillows, value 4s.; 2 blankets, value 4s.; 1 quilt, value 2s.; 1 looking-glass, value 10s, and 1 set of fire irons, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Adams
.

CAROLINE ADAMS
. I am the wife of
John Adams
- we live at Ratcliff
; I let a ready furnished room to the prisoner, containing the articles stated - I never allowed them to take any of them away.

WILLIAM LANCE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a bolster, two pillows, a looking-glass, a blanket, two sheets, a flat iron, and a set of fire irons pawned at different times, from November to June, chiefly by the female prisoner - she has two daughters who have pawned them; they were most of them pawned weekly, and taken out again on a Saturday night - I can speak positively to one thing the female prisoner pawned, and that is the looking-glass; it was pawned the last time on the 15th of June, and some days before she had pawned it for 5s., and then she had something more on it - these are the duplicates of the things.

JOSEPH HAWES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a bed, pawned by a woman, in the name of Mary Franklin - I do not know who by.

JAMES HENRY ANDREWS
(Police-constable K 104). I took the female prisoner, and found the duplicate of the bed on her.

EDWARD CALVER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a quilt, but I do not know who pawned it.

WILLIAM GRIFFIN
(Police-constable K 65.) I took the male prisoner, and found five duplicates on him, which relate to articles at the different pawnbrokers.

Samuel Franklin
Q. Where did I get them? A. I saw your wife give them to you in going to the watch-house.
CAROLINE ADAMS. These are my property - they continually kept the door locked, whether they were out or at home.

Simon Franklin
Q. Is the shovel yours? A. No, the tongs and poker are, and I have the shovel at home, which corresponds with them.

Simon Franklin
's Defence. I am innocent of all these pawnings - I did not know of the bed being pawned until after I was in custody; we had bed and bedding of our own besides - I had a daughter going to service, and to get her some things, I said I would pawn our bed, but my wife took this bed - I did not know the difference - I could not miss the other things, as we had things of every description; I belonged to the Police, in which I remained till 1831 - I then got a situation as a flax-dresser, and in October last I went to the prosecutor's.

CAROLINE ADAMS
. The quilt was the quilt off the bed, and the bolster and the pillows belonged to it; the prisoners had a bed, but it was a flock bed; they had no looking-glass.

Mary Ann Franklin
. I pawned the things unknown to my husband.
NOT GUILTY .

1708.
JAMES MUNROE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , 12 lbs., of wax candles, value 20s. , the goods of
Earl Vane
.
The candles being spermacetti, the prisoner was ACQUITTED .

1709.
HENRY BAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 2 elm logs, value 10l., the goods of
Joseph Fletcher
and others .

HENRY SKILLITH
. I am foreman to Mr. Joseph Fletcher; he has only one partner.
NOT GUILTY .

1710.
JOHN BAILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of December , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
William Gardiner
.

WILLIAM GARDINER
. I am a milkman and a shoemaker ; I live at Isleworth
. In the end of December I lost a coat from my cow-house, which was broken open - I did not see the coat again till the 21st of June - the prisoner was in our neighbourhood at the time I lost it - I had occasionally employed him.

JOHN GREGORY JACKSON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Hounslow. I have a blue great-coat, which I took in from Smith, on the 7th of January.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. What is Smith? A. A labouring woman - I asked who she brought it for; she said John Brown.

ELIZABETH SMITH
. I am a labouring woman. I pawned the coat - I was going up the town, and met the prisoner with
Thomas Flicker
- he was a soldier; he deserted, and was taken again, and is now in Ireland; the prisoner asked me to pawn the coat; I told him I never did such a thing, but as I knew Flicker I would - the prisoner had been carrying the coat - he gave it to Flicker, who gave it to me- he told me to ask 8s. for it, and I got 6s. - I pawned it in the name of John Brown, as I was told.

Cross-examined. Q. Who first spoke to you? A. Flicker did - the prisoner asked him to ask me - I gave the money to the prisoner, who put it into his right hand pocket, and the duplicate - he thanked me, and they said good day- I had not seen the prisoner before; but I knew Flicker.

ROBERT PARNHAM
. On the 4th of June, at half-past ten o'clock, the prosecutor gave Smith in charge; she told me where she got the coat, and I took the prisoner from her description.
Prisoner. She said she gave the money to Flicker, and he gave it to me, because he had holes in his pocket.
SMITH. No; he never touched it.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .
OLD COURT, THURSDAY, JULY 12.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr Sergeant Arabin .

1711.
ANDREW HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , 6 pewter measures, value 4s. , the goods of
Lucy Ann Dawson
.

The
prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1712.
JOHN HAWKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 2 planes, value 3s., and 6 gross of screws, value 6s. , the goods of
John Witney
.

WILLIAM WITNEY
. I am a carpenter. On the 5th of July, at eleven o'clock at night, I locked these things up in a counting-house in the yard, in White's-alley, Chancery-lane
, and at six in the morning I found the counting-house broken open, and property gone - the prisoner lives in a house adjoining the premises.

HENRY GAST
. I am a carpenter. I was with Witney, and saw the prisoner and his wife together; his wife had a bundle; they parted - the prisoner took the bundle from her, and offered the tools for sale at a shop in Wild-street; we then took him.

MICHAEL RUSSELL
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner with these things - I found a hammer in his room, which fits the marks on the counting-house door.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the bundle in White's-alley.

GUILTY . Aged 68 -
Confined One Year .

1713.
NATHANIEL HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 ivory image, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Charles Nicholas
.

CHARLES NICHOLAS
. I am a broker , and live at Hoxton
. On the 29th of June I saw the prisoner, with another boy , as I returned home; one of them stooped, which made me suspect them - I went home, and missed a carved ivory image of a lion, which is two hundred and thirty years old - I pursued, and found it in the prisoner's pocket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The other boy gave it to me.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Whipped and Discharged.
NEW COURT. THURSDAY. JULY 12.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before J. Mirehouse, Esq.

1714.
MICHAEL JORDAN
,
THOMAS WILKINSON
, and
RICHARD HAMMOND
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Duff William Rae
, from his person .

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a constable. On the 5th of July, about ten o'clock at night, I was in Goswell-street, and saw the three prisoners following two gentlemen - they then went into St. John-street, where I saw the prosecutor and another gentleman walking; they passed them, then turned, and followed them - I saw Jordan take a handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket, and give it to Hammond, who crossed the road with it, leaving the other two; I took hold of Hammond, who threw the handkerchief down - Cadby took up the handkerchief, and took the other two prisoners.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I am a constable. I was with Colton - we followed the prisoners for some time; when they got to St. John-street they followed the prosecutor and another gentleman, and just as they reached a tobacconist's shop I saw Jordan take the handkerchief out of the pocket, and give it to Hammond - Jordan and Wilkinson then sat down on the step by the tobacco-shop, which the prosecutor and his friend went into; Wilkinson must have seen the pocket picked, as he was close by; Hammond then crossed the way, and Colton took him - I picked up the handkerchief, and took the other two.

DUFF WILLIAM RAE
. I live in Bride-lane. I was walking in St. John-street
, and lost this handkerchief from my pocket - I did not miss it till I was told of it.
Jordan's Defence. I saw it on the pavement - I took it up, and gave it to Hammond, who crossed to see what it was.
Wilkinson's Defence. I do not know either of these lads; I was sitting on the step waiting for a person.
Hammond's Defence. I saw Jordan pick up the handkerchief - I said I had a right to have half of it, and he gave it me to look at.

JORDAN -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

WILKINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

HAMMOND -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Whipped and Discharged.

1715.
JOHN BIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 15 shillings, and 2 rings, the property of
George Perry
, from his person .

GEORGE PERRY
. I was lodging, on the 3rd of July, at the Marlborough Arms, St. Pancras
. I went to bed about eleven o'clock at night - the prisoner slept in another bed in the same room; I slept alone - when I went to bed, I had 15s. in shillings, and two sixpences in my pocket; I took it out, put it into a bit of paper, and put it into my right-hand breeches pocket, and a letter with it - I put my clothes in a chair by my bed-side - I awoke between seven and eight o'clock in the morning; the prisoner was then getting up - he seemed in a great hurry to dress; when he had left the room, I got out of bed, and found my clothes, which I had left in the chair, on the prisoner's bed - I felt in my breeches pocket, and my money and letter were gone; I could not tell the money, but I know the paper it was in.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not take a hand-bill in Oxford-street? A. No, it was given to me in Holborn - it was the only paper I had; I did not put my clothes on yours when I went to bed - I put them on the chair - there was nothing else there; I awoke while you were dressing.

COURT. Q. Did you find the letter or the money? A. I apprehended the prisoner myself, in about a quarter of an hour, or twenty minutes, and a Police-officer, who is not here, searched him in my room; he found on him this paper, in which my money had been, and 13s. 6d. - I found this letter, which had been in my pocket, in his bed; he afterwards said he gave 2s. 6d. for this new waistcoat - he made some resistance when the officer searched him.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Six Months .

1716.
JAMES YOUNG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June
, 2 pillows, value 5s.; 2 sheets, value 3s.; 1 quilt, value 1s. 6d., and 3 knives and forks, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Williams
.

MARY WILLIAMS
. I am the wife of
Thomas Williams
; we live in Vine-street, near Tabernacle-square
. About May, the prisoner came to lodge at our house - he had a furnished room, at 4s. a week; he brought a person with him, who he said was his wife - they staid a fortnight; one Saturday night, in June, I ran up stairs, to go into another room, and saw his wife there - I then heard the door shut - I went up stairs again, and they were both gone - it was then about ten o'clock; they had left one candle on the stairs, and one on the mantel-piece - I missed the articles stated - I saw them safe when he had been one week with me; he did not pay me any rent - I have not seen any of the things since; my husband took the prisoner afterwards; he brought him to our house, and gave him in charge - he did not say any thing in my hearing.

Prisoner. Q. What time did I leave your house? A. About eight o'clock you came, and about ten you left - no one went into the room after you left; I went up in ten minutes, or in five minutes after you were gone; I then missed the articles - the door was wide open - you left me without notice.

SAMUEL TAYLOR
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was suddenly thrown into prison, without the means of letting my friends know, or I should have been able to contradict a great part of the evidence against me; if the prosecutor had been here, I could have asked him a few questions, which would have been of great consequence - I was not in the house after seven o'clock that evening.
GUILTY . Aged 34.

1717.
JAMES YOUNG
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March
, 2 pillows, value 7s., and 1 blanket, value 7s. , the goods of
Charles Burrows
.

ELIZABETH BURROWS
. I am the wife of Charles Burrows: we live in Bunhill-row
. The prisoner took a furnished lodging at our house, on the 7th of March; he staid three weeks - he only paid one week's rent; on the 27th of March, at two o'clock, he borrowed a pen and ink, and soon afterwards I found the key of his door; I kept it till the next morning, when I called in an officer to open his room door; I found on the mantel-piece a small piece of writing, and the duplicate of two pillows and a blanket, which had been let to him with the room.

JOHN BURBRIDGE
. I am shopman to Mr. Sams, a pawnbroker. I have two pillows, which were pawned on the 16th, and on the 26th of March, in the names of David Franklin, and
James Franklin
; I have no knowledge of who pawned them.

REGINALD CHARLES OTTER
. I am shopman to Mr. Latter, a pawnbroker. I have a blanket, which was pawned on the 16th of March, by a man, for half a crown; I cannot say who - it was in the name of
James Franklin
.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1718.
JOSEPH SHEPHERD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 8 shillings, and 2d. , the monies of
Thomas Pimlott
.

MARY PIMLOTT
. I am the wife of
Thomas Pimlott
. On the 3rd of July, a sailor came to lodge at my house; the prisoner came with him - the prisoner gave me half a sovereign to fetch half a gallon of beer; I put the change on the mantel-piece, and the prisoner took it - it was the sailor's money, and he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1719.
WILLIAM SYKES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

WILLIAM OLIVER
(Police-constable M 51). On the 26th of June I was on duty in Hyde-park
. I was holding Colonel Rowan's horse, and saw the prisoner standing behind a crowd - I saw him take the handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket; he was making his escape - I secured him; he said, "I have done nothing, and have got nothing"- I said "I will see what you have got;" I felt down his trousers, and took out this handkerchief.

Prisoner. A woman came up, and said, she saw me take it off the grass, which I did. Witness. A woman came by and said, "Say you picked it off the grass," and I said,"You ought to be ashamed of yourself to tell the boy so;" I was obliged to take the prisoner back to the horse to secure him, and I lost sight of the gentleman.
NOT GUILTY .

1720.
BENJAMIN STANTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of June , 1 coat, value 17s., the goods of
George Farrant
and another .

PETER HALDANE
. I am shopman to George and
William Farrant
