; they are pawnbroker s. On the 23rd of June a coat was stolen from their door - I had seen it at half-past ten o'clock, and missed it about eleven; I saw it brought in by the officer, between seven and eight, the same evening.

WILLIAM LAW
(Police-constable H 88). On the day stated, I saw the prisoner go into a house in Wentworth-street; he hung this coat across a chair-back; I went in, and asked him who it belonged to - he said to Mr. Sheen, who was there asleep; I awoke him, and asked if it was his - he said, "No, I know nothing about it."

ANN SHEEN
. I am the daughter of
William Sheen
, of Wentworth-street. I was cleaning the door between twelve and one o'clock; the prisoner brought in this coat; the officer came in and took him away? - I never saw him before, I swear that; the door was open and he came in- my father is a wheelright; he was asleep on a table, as he had been out all night on a job.
Prisoner. They do know me, and her brother has been tried here. Witness. He may say so, but I never saw him in my life before.
Prisoner's Defence. My mother is dead, and my father has three of us to keep; these people buy things, and I went there to sell it.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1721.
ROBERT THOMPSON
and
SAMUEL RAWLINGS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of June , 1 ham, value 11s. , the goods of
Theophilus Walter
.

THEOPHILUS WALTER
. I live in Hoxton
, and am a cheesemonger . On the 22nd of June I had a ham hanging on the door of my shop; I missed it about eight o'clock in the morning - this is it.

FRANCIS FEATHERSTONE
(Police-constable N 88). On the 22nd of June I was on duty in Kingsland-road, about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's; I received information from Mr. Dyer, that two boys had gone down a court with a bag - I went down, and saw the two prisoners standing, and a bag on the ground, close to them; I examined it, and found in it this ham.

MARY ANN DYER
. I am the wife of
John Dyer
. I was standing at my door that morning, and saw two lads cross the road with a bag - they went down a gateway; I told the officer, who went and took them with the bag.

THOMAS HARRIS
. I am a sweep. I was in Fleming-street, and saw Thompson with a ham in his arms - he crossed the road, and Rawlings met him - they took a bag from a hearth-stone barrow and put it into it.

Thompson's Defence. I was coming down the street, and this lad asked me to carry it to Shoreditch church, and he would give me 3d. or 4d. - when we got to Kingsland road, he said, "Turn down this turning;" he then said, "Here are two Policemen coming;" I said, "You must have stolen the ham;" he then said, "Throw it away."
Rawlings' Defence. I took the ham - this lad is quite innocent.

RAWLINGS -
GUILTY - Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

THOMPSON -
NOT GUILTY .

1722.
EDWARD GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 1 pair of trousers, value 13s., the goods of
William Austin
; and 1 saw, value 2s., the goods of
John Lawson
.

FREDERICK LANCE
. I am in the employ of Mr. William Austin, a pawnbroker
, in High-street, Shadwell
. On the 2nd of July, about five o'clock in the afternoon, a person came into the shop, and told me a pair of trousers had been stolen - I went to the door, and the prisoner was pointed out to me; I went and took these trousers from under his jacket.

JOHN LAWSON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Ratcliffe-highway
. On the 2nd of July I lost a saw - in consequence of information I went and found the prisoner, and took it from his hand - I had seen it safe a quarter of an hour before.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been drinking very hard, and did not know what I did, until the next morning.

FREDERICK LANCE
. He was drunk, but not so drunk as he pretended to be; he walked very well until I took hold of him, and then he would not stand.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined One Month .

1723.
ANN SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 1 bonnet, value 1s. , the goods of
Stephen Eastland
.

REBECCA EASTLAND
. I am the wife of Stephen Eastland - I live in Green Arbour-court
. On the 13th of June I was at home, about nine o'clock in the evening; the prisoner came to my room, and said she wanted to speak to me - she went round by a small leaf-table, and sat down on a chair, by the side of which was a band-box, and a bonnet on it; she put her hand down, took the bonnet, and at the same time she got up and said, "I must go;" I had no candle in the house - I went to get my bonnet to fetch a candle and saw the bonnet in her right hand; I said,"Give me my bonnet, you hussey;" she opened the door, ran down stairs, and I after her - she ran into some alleys, where there are a great many low Irish people.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are not you and the prisoner well acquainted? A. No; I do not think I ever spoke to her above twice before this - I have seen her at the Goat; I gave her part of a pint of beer, which she begged of me the day this happened - I did not promise to lend her my bonnet that night; she was not in the room two minutes - my husband was in the room, but he saw nothing of it.
NOT GUILTY .

1724.
RICHARD CLAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 4 jackets, value 18s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 8s.; 3 shirts, value 6s.; 2 waistcoats, value 4s.; 6 stockings, value 1s. 6d., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
James Duggan
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1600.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , 2 pairs of shoes, value 4s., and 4 lasts, value 1s. , the goods of
Richard Lee
.

HANNAH LEE
. I am the wife of Richard Lee - he lives in Princes-place, St. George's
, and is a shoemaker . On Wednesday afternoon, the 4th of July, I heard a noise in the shop; I looked, and saw the prisoner stooping - I called to him "Halloo! halloo!" he ran out - I pursued him, crying Stop thief! but I did not know that he had stolen the shoes till I got to Mr. Smith's shop - I found these shoes and lasts there; I know they are my husband's- I saw him make them; they are not finished.

JOHN SMITH
. On Wednesday afternoon, the 4th of July I was having my tea in my back room at my house in King-street, Commercial-road; I heard a lumbering noise in front of my shop - I ran, and found these four shoes on the lasts, about one yard in the shop; I stood two or three minutes, and saw a mob - the officer and Mr. Lee came- I gave up the shoes to them.

WILLIAM BROCK
. About half-past five o'clock that evening I was coming by the prosecutor's shop ; I saw the prisoner come out with something under his coat; I heard Mrs. Lee call Stop thief! I pursued him down King-street, and assisted in taking him; I saw him pass Smith's shop, but did not see him throw any thing in there- I had only lost sight of him while he turned the corner.

WILLIAM REEVES
( Police-constable K 152). I heard the alarm as I was at the corner of Grove-street . I followed the prisoner, and saw some shoes under his coat, partly concealed; I pursued him to a street leading to King-street, where I lost sight of him; I got sight of him again in King-street, and told my brother officer to follow him.

THOMAS OWEN
( Police-constable H 176). I saw the prisoner running , and took him, he was very violent , and tried to get me down ; it took three of us to take him .
Prisoner's Defence . I ran with the mob , and was taken; the officer struck me .

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .
